{{UDP|date=August 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Aaron Frenkel | image = Aaron Frenkel.jpg | image_size = 230px | caption = Frenkel during interview with The Jerusalem Post, Jan 2016 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1957|09|09}} | birth_place = [[Bnei Brak]], [[Israel]] | birth_name = | death_date = | death_place = | residence = | nationality = | education = | occupation = [[Real estate]] Developer, [[Investor]] | known_for = Owner of the Loyd’s Group | ethnicity = | networth = | children = 5 | spouse = [[Maja Ruth Frenkel]] | parents = | family = | website = }}
'''Aaron G. Frenkel''' (born September 9, 1957 in [[Israel]]) is an international [[businessman]] and [[investor]].
== Career == Since the 1980s, Frenkel has been the owner of Loyd's Group of Companies, which deals with investments in the domains of property and [[real estate]],<ref name="bloomberg">{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2012-06-20/development-in-dubrovnik-means-seven-year-wait-for-barclays-fund|title=Dubrovnik’s Delayed Villas Highlight Obstacles for Barclays - Bloomberg Business|publisher=bloomberg.com|accessdate=2016-01-07}}</ref> [[civil aviation]] and [[aerospace]] industries, [[energy]] and [[hi-tech]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.intelligenceonline.com/insiders/2013/06/03/aaron-frenkel-the-aircraft-manufacturers--agent-of-choice,107962828-BE1|title=The aircraft manufacturers' agent of choice}}</ref> The group was formed as part of the efforts to develop the economies of central and [[eastern Europe]]. The development was concentrated at the time on sharing [[technology]], equipment, knowhow and capital from international companies in western countries interested, in contributing to their development and economic flourishing of the aforementioned countries.
As a representative of the main civil aviation industries<ref>{{cite web|title=Aviaition High Flyer|url=http://www.jpost.com/Magazine/Aviation-high-flyer-443066|website=jpost|publisher=Steve Linde}}</ref> in Central & Eastern Europe ([[The Boeing Company|Boeing]], [[Airbus]], [[Gulfstream Aerospace|Gulfstream]], [[Agusta]]), Frenkel established the Loyd’s Group,<ref>{{cite web|title=The aircraft manufacturers' agent of choice|url=https://www.intelligenceonline.com/insiders/europe_israel/2013/06/03/aaron-frenkel-the-aircraft-manufacturers--agent-of-choice/107962828-BE1|website=intelligenceonline}}</ref> aiming to bring western aviation products, advanced technology and equipment to these eastern countries. The company is estimated to be involved in investments of over 35 billion dollars In the last 25 years. The Group is involved in all stages of property development, starting from designing and planning to implementation and management.
== Commendations and awards == * The French Légion d'honneur, awarded by [[Nicolas Sarkozy]].<ref>{{cite web|title=AARON FRANKEL - KNOWN PHILANTHROPIST AND BUSINESSMAN|url=https://www.dyhanie.ru/content/view/80726/204/|website=dyhanie}}</ref> * Chairman of the Israeli Presidential Conference during the tenure of [[Shimon Peres]] as President of the State of Israel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://2013.presidentconf.org.il/en/speaker/mr-aaron-frenkel-monaco/|title=Aaron Frenkel, Monaco}}</ref> * Chevalier de L'ordre de Grimaldi Medal of Honour, presented by [[Albert II, Prince of Monaco]]. * Honorary Consul of the Republic of [[Croatia]] in [[Jerusalem]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Mr. Aaron Frenkel, Monaco|url=http://2013.presidentconf.org.il/en/speaker/mr-aaron-frenkel-monaco/|website=presidentconf}}</ref> * Mecenate of [[Russia]] awarded by the President of the [[Russian Federation]].<ref>{{cite web|title=מר אהרון פרנקל, מונקו|url=http://2013.presidentconf.org.il/speaker/%D7%9E%D7%A8-%D7%90%D7%94%D7%A8%D7%95%D7%9F-%D7%A4%D7%A8%D7%A0%D7%A7%D7%9C-%D7%99%D7%A9%D7%A8%D7%90%D7%9C/|website=presidentconf}}</ref> * Recipient of The Order of Friendship awarded by the President of the Russian Federation. <ref>{{Cite journal|date=2018-04-02|title=Order of Friendship|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Order_of_Friendship&oldid=833853441|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}}</ref> * Fellow Member of the [[Tel Aviv Museum of Art]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tamuseum.org.il/board-of-governers|title=Tel Aviv Museum of Art, International Board of Governors}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tamuseum.org.il/friends-event/14777|title=Tel Aviv Museum of Art - Monaco, August 3rd 2010}}</ref>
== Philanthropy == Limmud FSU was founded in 2006, and Frenkel serves as its President.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.limmudfsucanada.org/cms/?dd_staff=aaron-frenkel|title=Aaron Frenkel - Limmud FSU Canada|work=Limmud FSU Canada|access-date=2018-10-07|language=en-US}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://jewishnews.timesofisrael.com/limmud-fsu-well-reach-out-to-jews-keen-to-learn/|title=Limmud FSU: ‘We’ll reach out to Jews keen to learn’|access-date=2018-10-07|language=en-US}}</ref> Limmud FSU engages young Russian-Jewish adults and empowers them to take ownership of their identity and connect with their communities through pluralistic, egalitarian volunteer-driven conferences of Jewish learning and culture.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/Diaspora/Let-My-People-Know-406780|title=‘Let My People Know!’}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ejewishphilanthropy.com/2000-participants-attend-10th-anniversary-of-limmud-fsu-israel/|title=2,000 Participants attend 10th Anniversary of Limmud FSU Israel|website=ejewishphilanthropy.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-07}}</ref>
Frenkel funded and donated the Frenkel Emergency Medical Centre (FEMC), located at the Yad Sarah Centre Jerusalem in Sep 2017. FEMC includes medical imaging department, treatment rooms, laboratory and other facilities. This new emergency centre treats the milder emergency cases and those which do not require hospitalisation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.jpost.com/HEALTH-SCIENCE/Yad-Sarah-to-offer-urgent-nighttime-medical-care-in-Jerusalem-503848|title=Yad Sarah to offer urgent nighttime medical care in Jerusalem|work=The Jerusalem Post {{!}} JPost.com|access-date=2017-12-18}}</ref>
== Personal life==
Frenkel is married to [[Maja Ruth Frenkel]] and they have 5 children. They live in [[Monaco]].
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == {{commonscat|Aaron Frenkel}} * [http://jewishnews.timesofisrael.com/record-audience-cheers-on-the-jewish-russian-revival/ Record audience cheers on the Jewish Russian revival], timesofisrael * [http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Culture/Hebrew-University-unveils-new-statue-of-Albert-Einstein-on-Jerusalem-campus-404953 Hebrew University unveils new statue of Albert Einstein on Jerusalem campus], [[The Jerusalem Post]] 6 March 2015 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140829200407/http://www.presidentconf.org.il/uploads/file_1832416112011.pdf Aaron Frenkel, Chairman of the Israeli Presidential Conference] 2011 * [https://cftau.ca/events/tel-aviv-university-gala-dinner-monaco/ Tel Aviv University Gala Dinner in Monaco], cftau

{{Infobox person | name = Adrian Beecroft | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = | | death_place = | education = | occupation = [[Angel investor]] | spouse = Jacqueline Beecroft | residence = [[London]] and [[Oxford]], [[United Kingdom]] | children = }}
'''Paul Adrian Barlow Beecroft''' (born Yorkshire 20 May 1947<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.freebmd.org.uk/cgi/information.pl?cite=JiyMi1qc8tMfb1IhqEwzeQ&scan=1|title=Index entry |accessdate=25 May 2012 |work=FreeBMD|publisher=ONS}}</ref>) is a [[British People|British]] [[venture capitalist]] based in [[London]]. He was for many years [[Chief Investment Officer]] of the [[private equity]] group [[Apax]]. He was until recently [[Chairman]] of Dawn Capital.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dawncapital.co.uk/ |title=Home |publisher=Dawn Capital |date= |accessdate=2012-05-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Apax veteran Beecroft returns to VC roots|author=Financial News|date=25 May 2010|url=http://www.efinancialnews.com/story/2010-05-25/adrian-beecroft-dawn-capital}}</ref>
Among the companies Beecroft has personally invested in are [[Mimecast]] and Insignis.
Beecroft has donated more than £500,000 to the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] since 2006.<ref>{{cite news|title=Beecroft proposals: how Tory donor's radical blueprint split the government|author=The Guardian|date=23 May 2012|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2012/may/23/beecroft-proposals-coalition-support-criticism|location=London}}</ref>
== Early life and education == Adrian Beecroft was born and raised in Yorkshire. He studied at [[Hymers College]] in Hull.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/3664641/The-New-Philanthropists.html|title=The New Philanthropists|last=Thomas|first=David|date=2007-04-20|access-date=2018-09-04|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref>
He graduated from [[Queen's College, Oxford|Queen’s College, Oxford]] with a first class honours degree in Physics in 1968 and is now an Honorary Fellow of the College.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=85311&privcapId=35903973|title=Profile: Adrian Beecroft|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bloomberg.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-04}}</ref> In 1976 he gained a M.B.A from Harvard Business School, where he studied as a [[Harkness Fellowship|Harkness Fellow]].<ref name=":0" /> He graduated from Harvard as a [[Baker scholar|Baker Scholar]].<ref name=":0" />
== Career == Adrian Beecroft has an extensive career in venture capital and private equity, specialising in IT investments.<ref name=":0" /> He was the Chairman of the [[British Venture Capital Association]] in 1991.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/business-big-shot-adrian-beecroft-032nzk2kkxq|title=Business big shot: Adrian Beecroft|date=2010-05-25|work=The Times|access-date=2018-09-04|language=en|issn=0140-0460}}</ref>
Beecroft started his career at ICL, in the computer industry.<ref name=":1" /> In 1973 he moved to Ocean Transport and Trading Ltd., working to develop their new business area of bulk shipping.<ref name=":0" />
After graduating from Harvard Business School, he joined [[Boston Consulting Group]] in London. He became Vice President of BCG in 1982.<ref name=":0" />
In 1984, Beecroft joined Apax Partners, and was there for 25 years until he retired from his role as [[Chief investment officer|Chief Investment Officer]] in 2008.<ref name=":1" /> While working at Apax, he served as their representative on the boards of over 20 public and private companies, including [[Computacenter]], Alkane Energy and [[Healthcare at Home]]. He played a significant part in the international expansion of the business, which now has over $20 billion under management.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/person/adrian-beecroft|title=Adrian Beecroft|last=|first=|date=|website=Crunchbase|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-04}}</ref>
In December 2006 Beecroft was appointed to the [[NESTA]] Investment Committee.<ref>http://www.official-documents.gov.uk/document/hc0607/hc06/0654/0654.pdf</ref> At that time NESTA was still a [[QUANGO]].
Beecroft was awarded the BVCA’s Hall of Fame honour at the Private Equity Awards in 2009.<ref name=":0" /> He was a member of [[Sir David Walker|Sir David Walker’s]] committee on improving the transparency of the private equity industry.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ftalphaville.ft.com/2007/03/21/3305/walker-assembles-high-flying-private-equity-working-group/|title=Walker Assembles High Flying Private Equity Working Group|last=|first=|date=|website=ftalphaville.ft.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-04}}</ref>
In 2010, Beecroft joined Dawn Capital as the Chairman of their board.<ref name=":1" />
==Beecroft Report and controversy== On 21 May 2012, the Beecroft Report caused considerable controversy in the UK due to its recommendations to relax regulation surrounding the dismissal of employees. The report claimed this would help to boost the economy.<ref>{{cite news|title=How Adrian Beecroft proposed to rip up decades of employee rights to boost the economy|author=Daily Telegraph|date=21 May 2012|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/9275558/Analysis-How-Adrian-Beecroft-proposed-to-rip-up-decades-of-employee-rights-to-boost-the-economy.html|location=London|work=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref> It was alleged that significant sections of the report had been doctored.<ref name=":2">{{cite news|title=Controversial Beecroft report on employment reform doctored by No 10|author=Daily Telegraph|date=21 May 2012|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/9281161/Controversial-Beecroft-report-on-employment-reform-doctored-by-No-10.html|location=London|work=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref> It was also reported that some recommendations had been removed from the original draft of the report.<ref name=":2" /> On 21 May [[Secretary of State for Business]] [[Vince Cable]] condemned the report, saying it was unnecessary for the government to scare workers.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-18155827 |title=BBC News - Adrian Beecroft work report not doctored, No 10 says |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= 2012-05-22|accessdate=2012-05-22}}</ref> Beecroft responded by accusing Cable of being a socialist.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/9283748/Socialist-Vince-Cable-not-fit-for-office-says-Adrian-Beecroft.html|title='Socialist' Vince Cable not fit for office, says Adrian Beecroft|last=Winnett|first=Robert|date=2012-05-22|access-date=2018-09-05|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> He referenced his own experience of having to pay £150,000 for unfairly dismissing an HR employee as one of the many reasons behind the recommendation in the report.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/9283748/Socialist-Vince-Cable-not-fit-for-office-says-Adrian-Beecroft.html |title='Socialist' Vince Cable not fit for office, says Adrian Beecroft |publisher=Telegraph |date=2011-05-31 |accessdate=2012-05-22 |location=London |first=Robert |last=Winnett}}</ref>
==Philanthropy== Beecroft helped to found and funds the Beecroft Institute of Particle Physics and Cosmology (BIPAC)<ref name=":3" /> at [[Oxford University]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.physics.ox.ac.uk/astro/bipac/ |title=Beecroft Institute of Particle Astrophysics and Cosmology |publisher=Physics.ox.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-05-22}}</ref> He has also part-funded the Beecroft building in Oxford. This new building is specifically focused on [[Theoretical physics|theoretical]], [[Condensed matter physics|condensed matter]] and [[Quantum (physics)|quantum]] physics. According to the Telegraph, the funding for this building was inspired by Beecroft’s interest in Astrophysics.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.campaign.ox.ac.uk/news/beecroft-building|title=Celebrating the ‘bottoming out’ of Oxford’s Beecroft Building|last=|first=|date=|website=www.campaign.ox.ac.uk|language=en-gb|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-07}}</ref><ref name=":3" />
Beecroft has also supported his school, Hymer’s College in Hull.<ref name=":3" /> He has also been a Trustee of Impetus Trust, a social impact charity.<ref name=":3" /> Beecroft was also for six years the Chairman of the Cricket Foundation, now known as [[Chance to Shine]], a charity focused on bringing cricket back into British state school education.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.chancetoshine.org/news/cricket-foundation-elects-donald-brydon-as-new-chairman-of-the-board-of-trustees|title=Cricket Foundation elects Donald Brydon as new Chairman of the Board of Trustees|last=|first=|date=|website=www.chancetoshine.org|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-07}}</ref>
Through the Beecroft Trust, Adrian and his wife sponsor the [[Oxford Academy, Oxfordshire|Oxford Academy]], an Academy school serving a very deprived area of Oxford.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theoxfordacademy.org.uk/Sponsors|title=Sponsors|last=|first=|date=|website=www.theoxfordacademy.org.uk|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-07}}</ref> Since becoming an Academy school in 2010, its results have improved dramatically from 14% of the students achieving five A* to C grades including English and Maths to 56% achieving this in 2017.
Mr Beecroft has also supported the [[UNESCO]] initiative to preserve the [[Belize Barrier Reef]] Reserve System, which was classified as in danger on the UNESCO List of World Heritage in Danger in 2009.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/news/1839/|title=Landmark Conservation Action leads to Belize Barrier Reef removal from List of World Heritage in Danger|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2018-09-07}}</ref> As of June 2018, the [[World Heritage Committee]] decided to remove the Belize Barrier Reef, which is the world’s second largest coral reef, from the list.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-44627719|title=Belize reef taken off 'in danger' list|date=2018-06-27|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-09-07|language=en-GB}}</ref>
==Personal life== Beecroft lives in [[London]] and supports [[Lord's|Lord’s Cricket Ground]] as a [[Marylebone Cricket Club]] (MCC) Trustee.<ref name=":4">{{Citation|last=Lord's Cricket Ground|title=Meet MCC Trustee Adrian Beecroft {{!}} MCC/Lord's|date=2015-09-29|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QqN_NLDNxVw|access-date=2018-09-07}}</ref> As a trustee one of his core roles is assisting with the appointment of the Chairman, but also overseeing the wellbeing of the club and cricket ground.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lords.org/mcc/the-club/mcc-committee/|title=MCC Committee|website=www.lords.org|language=en|access-date=2018-09-07}}</ref> His enthusiasm for the sport came from watching the [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club|Yorkshire County team]] play in Hull.<ref name=":4" /> He is the President of Cropredy Cricket Club for whom he still plays league cricket.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cropredycc.play-cricket.com/website/player_stats_widget/batting_stats/142168|title=Cropredy CC|website=cropredycc.play-cricket.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-07}}</ref>
Beecroft is a supporter of the [[North Yorkshire Moors Railway]] of which he is a Vice-President. He is a keen auto-enthusiast, having an extensive collection of vehicles, including several [[Aston Martin]]s, most notably a [[Aston Martin DBR1|DBR1]] which he races at a number of motoring events and later crashed in 2015.<ref>http://carbuzz.com/m/Article.aspx?Id=29621</ref> He is a governor of [[Hymers College]] in Hull.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Beecroft, Adrian}} [[Category:1947 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Angel investors]] [[Category:British businesspeople]] [[Category:Conservative Party (UK) people]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Oxford]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]]

'''Aubrey Dan''' (born October 4, 1963) is a Canadian [[businessman]] and [[philanthropist]] as well as a [[theatrical producer|producer]] and [[impresario]].<ref name="PostCity">{{cite web|url=http://postcitymagazines.com/2008-06/story_200806_AubreyDan.php |title=T.O.'s newest theatre mogul on his battle with Mirvish, his favourite musical and why he loves to call North York home |last=Nayman |first=Adam |date=June 2008 |publisher=postcitymagazines.com |accessdate=2009-05-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120095350/http://postcitymagazines.com/2008-06/story_200806_AubreyDan.php |archivedate=November 20, 2008 }}</ref><ref name="IBDB">{{cite web|url=http://www.ibdb.com/person.php?id=446166|title=Aubrey Dan|publisher=Internet Broadway Database|accessdate=2009-05-08}}</ref> He is the son of [[Leslie Dan]], a Canadian [[entrepreneur]] and founder of the generic pharmaceutical manufacturer [[Teva Canada|Novopharm]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://network.nationalpost.com/np/blogs/francis/archive/2009/01/17/jersey-boys-showbiz-and-aubrey-dan.aspx |title=Jersey Boys, showbiz and Aubrey Dan |last=Francis |first=Diane |date=January 17, 2009 |publisher=National Post |accessdate=2009-05-08 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He graduated from the University of Western Ontario and received a Bachelor of Management and Organizational Studies. The department was later renamed after Aubrey Dan in 2006, and is now called the DAN Department of Management & Organizational Studies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dan.uwo.ca/news/2017/DAN_management__renamed.html|title=DAN Department of Management & Organizational Studies named in honour of Aubrey Dan.|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
==Business ventures== According to the Dancap website, Dan founded a number of companies under the Dancap moniker including: Dancap Private Equity, Dancap Global Asset Management, [[Dancap Productions]] and Dancap Catering.<ref name="Dancap">{{cite web|url=http://www.dancap.ca/team.htm|title= Dancap Profile/Team |publisher=Dancap Private Equity Inc.|accessdate=2009-05-08}}</ref>
==Philanthropy== As a philanthropist, Dan has donated millions to various charitable organizations including: $5 million to the Baycrest Centre Foundation;<ref name="Baycrest">{{cite web|url=http://www.baycrest.org/News_and_Media/News_Releases_2004/default_6771.asp |title=$5-million gift to Baycrest honors father - Baycrest |publisher=Baycrest Center |accessdate=2009-05-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090813032202/http://www.baycrest.org/News_and_Media/News_Releases_2004/default_6771.asp |archivedate=2009-08-13 |df= }}</ref> $8 million to the Sunnybrook Foundation's Centre for High Risk Mothers & Babies;<ref name="TorStar">{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/News/GTA/article/307889|title=Sunnybrook gets $8M gift|last=Rush |first=Curtis |date=Feb 28, 2008|publisher=The Toronto Star|accessdate=2009-05-08}}</ref> and $350,000 to Ontario Wound Care Inc. for the [[hyperbaric]] oxygen treatment of diabetic wounds.<ref name="OntarioWoundCare">{{cite web|url=http://www.newswire.ca/en/releases/archive/March2007/22/c5341.html|title=New clinic treats diabetic wounds, prevents amputations |publisher=CNW Group Ltd. |accessdate=2009-05-08}}</ref>
On 7 April 2016, the School of Drama and Music at [[Queen's University]] was renamed the Dan School of Drama and Music in recognition of a $5-million donation from Dan, whose daughter is a graduate of the school's Drama program.<ref>http://www.queensjournal.ca/story/2016-04-07/arts/school-of-drama-and-music-receives-5-million-donation/</ref>
==Awards and recognition== Additional accolades for Dan include an [[Honorary degree|honorary Doctorate of Laws Degree]] from [[Assumption University (Windsor)|Assumption University]] in 2008.<ref name="Daiji">{{cite web|url=http://www.daijiworld.com/news/news_disp.asp?n_id=46614&n_tit=Akshay+Kumar+Conferred+PhD+by+Canada+University|title=Akshay Kumar Conferred PhD by Canada University|publisher=Daijiworld.com|accessdate=2009-05-08}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.dancap.ca/team.htm Dancap website and Aubrey Dan Bio]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dan, Aubrey}} [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Canadian businesspeople]] [[Category:Canadian Jews]] [[Category:Canadian philanthropists]] [[Category:Canadian people of Hungarian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:University of Western Ontario alumni]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{for|Benjamin Hall Blyth (1849-1917)|Benjamin Blyth II}}
[[File:Grave of Benjamin Blyth, Grange Cemetery.JPG|thumb|Grave of Benjamin Blyth, Grange Cemetery]] '''Benjamin Hall Blyth''' (14 July 1819 – 21 August 1866) was a [[Scotland|Scottish]] [[civil engineer]].<ref name="DSA">{{Cite web |url=http://www.codexgeo.co.uk/dsa/architect_full.php?id=M000434 |title=Dictionary of Scottish Architects entry |access-date=5 January 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719012038/http://www.codexgeo.co.uk/dsa/architect_full.php?id=M000434 |archive-date=19 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Life==
Blyth was born at 26 Minto St in [[Newington, Edinburgh]]<ref>Old Parish Record of birth/christening</ref> the son of Robert Brittain Blyth, an iron merchant, and his wife, Barbara Cooper. He was their third son, and the first to survive to adulthood.
Blyth was trained as a railway engineer under an apprenticeship with Grainger & [[John Miller (engineer)|Miller]], a railway contractor. In 1848 he established an engineering practice on the prestigious [[George Street, Edinburgh|George Street]] (at no 124) in [[Edinburgh]] where it would remain for the next 100 years. In 1854, after his brother Edward Lawrence Ireland Blyth finished his own apprenticeship with Grainger & Miller, Benjamin took him into partnership of the renamed ''B & E Blyth''.
The practice did work for the [[Caledonian Railway|Caledonian]], [[Glasgow and South Western Railway|Glasgow and South Western]], [[Scottish Central Railway|Scottish Central]], [[Dundee and Perth Railway|Dundee and Perth]], [[Great North of Scotland Railway|Great North of Scotland]] and [[Portpatrick Railway|Portpatrick]] railway companies.<ref name="DSA" />
Blyth was a first cousin of [[Arthur Blyth]], who was three times premier of South Australia in the 19th century. Their fathers were brothers.<ref name="Blyth, E.L.I 1893">Blyth, E.L.I. 1893, The family of Blythe or Blyth of Norton and Birchet</ref>
Blyth married Mary Dudgeon Wright in Leith, Edinburgh, on 1 August 1848.<ref>Marriage certificate, held by Scottish records office</ref> They initially lived at 26 Minto Street in the south of Edinburgh.<ref>Edinburgh and Leith Post Office Directory 1850-51</ref> Mary took on clerical duties in the early stages of Blyth's company.<ref>Blyth and Blyth: The First 100 Years, historical records held by company</ref> From 1854 they lived at 12 Hope Terrace, Edinburgh.<ref>http://www.westblacket.org.uk/rhcontent/people.htm</ref>
Blyth died from diabetes<ref>Death certificate, held by Scottish records office</ref> aggravated by overwork at home in [[North Berwick]] on 21 August 1866 and is buried in the [[Grange, Edinburgh|Grange Cemetery]], being survived by his wife, seven sons and two daughters.<ref name="DSA" /><ref name="Blyth, E.L.I 1893" />
His wife died of meningitis in 1868, and their children were subsequently brought up by his wife's sister, Elizabeth Scotland Wright. His eldest son [[Benjamin Blyth II]] took over his father's practice<ref name="son">{{Cite web |url=http://www.codexgeo.co.uk/dsa/architect_full.php?id=M000436 |title=Dictionary of Scottish Architects son's entry |access-date=5 January 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719012137/http://www.codexgeo.co.uk/dsa/architect_full.php?id=M000436 |archive-date=19 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and the company remains in business to this day as Blyth and Blyth.<ref name="Blyth">[http://www.blythandblyth.co.uk/about.php Blyth and Blyth]</ref>
His house served as the offices of [[Scottish Natural Heritage]] between 1950 and 2003 then reverted to its use as a family home.<ref name="house">[http://www.edinburgharchitecture.co.uk/hope_terrace_grange.htm Edinburgh Architecture entry]</ref>
==Employees== The harbour engineer, [[William Dyce Cay]], worked under Blyth on the [[Castle Douglas]] to [[Portpatrick]] Railway in 1861.<ref>http://www.scottisharchitects.org.uk/architect_full.php?id=404238</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}

'''Charles Edward Michael Terry''', [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]] (1897 – 13 April 1980) was a Hong Kong businessman. He was an [[unofficial member]] of the [[Executive Council of Hong Kong|Executive Council]] and [[Legislative Council of Hong Kong]].
Terry was an appointed [[unofficial member]] of the [[Legislative Council of Hong Kong]] from 1950 to 1959. He was an unofficial member of the [[Executive Council of Hong Kong]] until he was succeeded by [[Richard Charles Lee]] on 28 May 1961.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=41420|page=3778|date=13 June 1958}}</ref> He was the president of the St. Patrick's Society of Hong Kong in 1941. In 1952, he became the founding commissioner of the [[Civil Aid Service]], a civil organisation that assist in a variety of auxiliary emergency roles, and chairman of the [[Hong Kong St. John Ambulance]] in 1963.
He was awarded Officer and Commander of the [[Order of the British Empire]] (OBE and CBE) in 1955 and 1959 respectively for his public services in Hong Kong.<ref>{{London Gazette|supp=y|issue=41727|page=3720|date=13 June 1959}}</ref> In 1963, he was awarded Officer of the [[Order of Saint John (chartered 1888)|Order of the Hospital of St. John of Jerusalem]].<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=42896|page=507|date=15 January 1963}}</ref> He died in Queensland, Australia in April 1980.<ref>[https://www.ancestry.ca/interactive/1904/46452_b294270-00179?pid=21593332&backurl=https://search.ancestry.ca/cgi-bin/sse.dll?indiv%3D1%26dbid%3D1904%26h%3D21593332%26tid%3D%26pid%3D%26usePUB%3Dtrue%26_phsrc%3DOzZ4353%26_phstart%3DsuccessSource&treeid=&personid=&hintid=&usePUB=true&_phsrc=OzZ4353&_phstart=successSource&usePUBJs=true Charles Edward Michael Terry death record]]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

[[File:Chocnut 01.jpg|thumb|A bag of Choc Nut and individually-wrapped pieces]] [[File:Chocnut display.jpg|thumb|Packets of Choc Nut for sale at a 'Filipino' Store in Sydney, Australia.]]
King '''Choc Nut''' (or '''tsoknat''') is a chocolate product manufactured by Unisman and later, Annie’s Sweets Manufacturing and Packaging Corporation.<ref name="loresco">{{cite web|last1=Loresco|first1=Shadz|title=Where's My Choc Nut?|url=http://www.rappler.com/business/features/95562-king-choc-nut-supply-demand|website=rappler.com|accessdate=7 August 2017}}</ref> It originated in the Philippines and has endured as one of the country’s most consumed children's snacks. While only mass-produced in the Philippines, many ‘Filipino stores’ abroad sell the item. Ingredients of Choc Nut include coconut milk., crushed peanuts and cocoa powder, resulting in a distinct nutty taste and crumbly texture. <ref name="loresco"/><ref name="verdolaga"/<ref name="quiogue">{{cite web|last1=Quiogue|first1=Monette|title=Going Nuts Over Choc Nut|url=http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/15437/going-nuts-over-choc-nut/|website=inquirer.net|accessdate=7 August 2017}}</ref>
== Manufacturing history ==
King Choc Nut was originally manufactured by a company called Unisman (New Unity Sweets Manufacturing Corporation) in Malabon. However, the new information on the packaging indicates that the product has now been bought out by Annie’s Sweets, the rival company that produced Hany, a chocolate bar with similar ingredients. <ref name="loresco"/> [[File:Chocnut pack.jpg|thumb|Details of King Choc Nut's new manufacturer printed on the outside of the packet]]
== Distribution ==
Choc Nut was usually available in convenience (sari-sari) stores and could be bought individually. However, some time after the brand was acquired by Annie’s Sweets, Choc Nut began to dwindle in supply, being replaced in most grocery and convenience stores by chocolate bar with similar taste and ingredients called Hany.<ref name="loresco"/> Today Choc Nut is predominantly found in supermarkets where they can be purchased by the pack. The brand is also imported to overseas retailers such as ‘Filipino stores’ popular in other countries around the world, where they are sold alongside various local products.<ref name="quiogue"/>
== Packaging ==
A pack of Choc Nut contains 24 pieces individually wrapped in silver foil and white paper, later plastic, on the outer side bearing the logo and signature red stripes. The packs are a bronze colour with white and red lines running through it horizontally.
In the early days of its manufacturing, Choc Nut wrappers printed promos or collectibles on the inside of the wrapper. This was eventually discontinued.<ref name="quiogue"/>
== Related products ==
King Choc Nut manufacturers also sell a powdered milk version of the sweet.
Many restaurants and cafes in the Philippines use Choc Nut as a popular ingredient in confections, drinks and even martinis.<ref name="loresco"/><ref name="verdolaga">{{cite web|last1=Verdolaga|first1=Gina|title=Chocnut-Crazy|url=https://www.pinoydelikasi.com/html/inside_featuredarticle.php|website=Pinoy Delikasi|accessdate=8 August 2017}}</ref>
== See also == * [[List of candies]] * [[Sari-sari store]]
== References == {{reflist}}

'''Cockburn’s Port''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|k|oʊ|b|ɜr|n|z}} {{respell|KOH|burnz}}) is a [[port wine|port]] producer in [[Portugal]].
Cockburn’s was set up by Scotsman Robert Cockburn in 1815,<ref>{{cite news|last1=McKenna|first1=Gemma|title=Cockburn’s Port lines up year of celebrations for bicentenary|url=http://www.harpers.co.uk/news/cockburns-port-lines-up-year-of-celebrations-for-bicentenary/512277.article|accessdate=7 November 2015|publisher=Harper's}}</ref> who returned to [[Portugal]] after first visiting the country as a soldier fighting under [[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington|Wellington]] in the [[Napoleonic Wars]]. It later became a major brand of port in the 19th and 20th centuries.
In 1962, the family sold the company to [[Harvey’s of Bristol]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Voss|first1=Roger|title=An Exclusive Tasting of Cockburn’s Centuries-Old, Yet Drinkable Ports|url=http://www.winemag.com/Web-2015/An-Exclusive-Tasting-of-Cockburns-Centuries-Old-Yet-Drinkable-Ports/|accessdate=7 November 2015|publisher=Wine Enthusiast}}</ref> which itself then became part of [[Allied Domecq]] until 2005, when Allied Domecq was taken over by [[Pernod Ricard]], which sold Cockburn's and some other brands to the [[Fortune Brands]] holding company (the parent company of Beam Global). In 2010 Cockburn's was sold to [[Symington Family Estates]], a family-owned business that owns over 1,006 hectares (2,400 acres) of vineyards in the [[Douro]] valley.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McKenna|first1=Gemma|title=Cockburn’s Port lines up year of celebrations for bicentenary|url=http://www.harpers.co.uk/news/cockburns-port-lines-up-year-of-celebrations-for-bicentenary/512277.article|accessdate=7 November 2015|publisher=Harper's}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.cockburns.com Cockburn's]

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{Cleanup|date=April 2009}} {{COI|date=August 2018}} }} '''Craig S. Fleisher''' is a scholar, advisor and author who has written or edited several important books in the fields of public affairs, business insight and competitive intelligence and [[Competitor analysis|analysis]].<ref>(Amazon.com, 2008; JCIM, 2003 volume 1)</ref> Before becoming [[Dean (education)|Dean]] of the Business School at the [[College of Coastal Georgia]], he was awarded two endowed research chair positions while a Professor of Business (Strategy & Environment) at the [[Odette School of Business]], [[University of Windsor]], [[Ontario]], Canada. His research addresses phenomena in the areas of business and [[competitive intelligence]], [[Public Affairs Council|corporate public affairs]] (government relations and [[lobbying]]), and performance management and measurement. Since 2011 Dr. Fleisher has served as the Chief Learning Officer of Aurora WDC, a 20+ year old professional services firm (PSF) headquartered in [[Madison, Wisconsin]], USA.<ref>(aurorawdc.com)</ref>
==Background, education and academic career== Fleisher received his PhD in Business from the [[Katz Graduate School of Business]], [[University of Pittsburgh]], his MBA in Human Resource Management and Marketing from the [[Vanderbilt University Owen Graduate School of Management|Owen Graduate School of Management]], Vanderbilt University, and BSBA in Finance, Insurance and Real Estate from the [[University of Florida]]. He also held positions in mortgage banking management, [[real estate appraisal]], and management consulting at various points in his career. After getting his PhD, he took an appointment at the [[University of Calgary]] as Associate Professor in the Policy and Environment area, spent nearly a decade in various professorial and program leadership roles at the School of Business and Economics at [[Wilfrid Laurier University]] in [[Waterloo, Ontario]], and was at the [[University of Windsor]] in endowed chair position for nearly a decade, following a couple of years in decanal positions at the [[University of New Brunswick]]. He serves as an Adjunct Professor in Business Information Management at [[Tampere University of Technology]] (Finland), Adjunct Professor at the [[Wisconsin School of Business]], [[University of Wisconsin]] in Madison, imember of the graduate faculty for the Executive MScom at the [[Università della Svizzera italiana]] in [[Lugano, Switzerland]], has also served as a visiting professor or scholar at the [[University of Sydney]] ([[Australia]]), [[De Montfort University]] (Leicester, UK), [[University of Western Sydney]]¨and [[University of Waikato]] (Hamilton, New Zealand), among others.
He is considered an expert in the business or [[competitive intelligence]] and analysis area<ref>(Dishman, Fleisher & Knip, 2002; Fleisher, Wright & Tindale, 2007; Fleisher, Knip & Dishman, 2003; Knip, Dishman, & Fleisher, 2003;</ref> based on the number of cited pieces (see [[Google Scholar]] for the most current citation counts of his work) he has written or the level of sales his writings have achieved, as well as in the area of corporate public affairs<ref>(Allen, 2006)</ref> where his books have been positively reviewed or named as best-sellers by leading associations and groups in the field. He was globally recognized for his lifetime contributions to the field of competitive intelligence by being named the Meritorious award winner and Fellow of the [[Society of Competitive Intelligence Professionals]] (Alexandria, Virginia, USA),<ref>(SCIP, 2001)</ref> and his efforts in graduate teaching led him to be named one of Canada's top MBA professors by ''[[Canadian Business Magazine]]'' in 2006. He has been interviewed about his expertise and research by leading media outlets for magazines, narrow-cast web publications, newspaper, radio and television in a variety of countries, most notably Australia, Canada, and the USA.
==Research and writing== Fleisher's academic research primarily focuses on two distinct areas of business activity, business and competitive intelligence, and corporate public affairs. Fleisher's dissertation was in the area of measuring public affairs performance,<ref>Fleisher, Craig (1991). "''Modeling the Role of Evaluation and Measurement in the Achievement of Corporate Public Affairs Management Effectiveness''" (OCLC: 28924435), 1991, Pittsburgh, PA: University of Pittsburgh</ref> and his research on public affairs benchmarking, performance measurement, and management is among the most cited according to [[Google Scholar]] in this field.<ref>Dishman, Fleisher, & Knip, 2003; Fleisher, Wright & Tindale, 2007; Fleisher, Knip & Dishman, 2003; Knip, Dishman, & Fleisher, 2003)</ref> His two books on these topics, published in 1995 and 1998 by the [[Public Affairs Council]] which is headquartered in [[Washington, DC]] were recognized as the Council's best-sellers at their time. His other major contributions in the field of corporate and public affairs are the two scholarly handbooks "The SAGE Handbook of International Corporate and Public Affairs" in 2017 and the ''Handbook of Public Affairs'' ([[SAGE Publications|Sage]], 2005) with his colleague Dr. Phil Harris from [[University of Chester]], [[United Kingdom]].
Since 2000, Fleisher is well known for his work in the area of business insights and [[competitive intelligence]], particularly in pushing for the professionalization of the field.<ref>(Fleisher, 2003)</ref> He published 3 edited volumes with his [[Wilfrid Laurier University]] [[Marketing]] professorial colleague David Blenkhorn, those being ''Managing Frontiers in Competitive Intelligence'' in 2001 (Quorum Books, an imprint of the [[Greenwood Publishing Group]]), ''Controversies in Competitive Intelligence'' published in 2003 and ''Global Business and Competitive Intelligence'' in 2005 by [[Praeger Publishers]].
The only [[Canadians|Canadian]] Winner of the international [[Society of Competitive Intelligence Professionals]] Meritorious Award for his lifetime contributions to the field of competitive intelligence, he may be best known for his two books looking at analysis methods used by consultants and practitioners in applied strategy. This included ''Strategic and Competitive Analysis'' with his colleague and fellow SCIP Meritorious Award winner [[Babette Bensoussan]] [[(Prentice Hall]], 2003) and ''Business and Competitive Analysis'' also with Bensoussan, (2Ed., [[Pearson PLC]], 2015, and [[FT Press]], 2007), and "Analysis without Paralysis" (w/Bensoussan, 2nd Ed., [[FT Press]], 2015). These books provided background and application information for over 50 separate methods of understanding business phenomena and competition,<ref>(Fleisher & Bensoussan, 2003; Fleisher & Bensoussan, 2007)</ref> ranging from popular methods like [[SWOT analysis]], financial ratio & statement analysis, [[critical success factor]] analysis, issue analysis, and S-curves to less popular but no less important methods including business model analysis, linchpin analysis, and alternative competing hypotheses.<ref>(Booknews, 2007)</ref> These books also address [[competitor analysis]].
==Other professional experience== In addition to his work in academia, Fleisher has served as President of the [[Board of Directors]] of the [[Society of Competitive Intelligence Professionals]] ([[Alexandria, Virginia]], USA), inaugural chair of the Competitive Intelligence Foundation (Washington, DC) - an organization that he also founded and helped launch with then SCIP Executive Director Alexander Graham, President of the Canadian Council for Public Affairs Advancement, Editor of the ''Journal of Competitive Intelligence and Management'', Associate Editor of the ''Journal of Public Affairs'' published by [[John Wiley & Sons]], and on the editorial boards of the ''International Journal of Technology Intelligence and Planning'' (Inderscience Publishers), ''Asia Pacific Public Relations Journal'', ''South African Journal of Information Management'', ''Competitive Intelligence Review'', ''Public Affairs'', and SCIP Online. He is also a long-time contributor to the Academy of Management's Social Issues in Management division, a founding member of the International Association of Business and Society, a life member of the [[International Association of Business Communicators]], an academic board member of the European Centre for Public Affairs, and a 2007 Canadian award-winning faculty advisor for the [[Golden Key International Honour Society]].
Fleisher also speaks globally on his research, having been to over two score different countries in a variety of roles ranging from key-noting conferences and meetings to serving as an authoritative panel member. He regularly shares his research and expertise to corporate groups, executive audiences, professional and trade associations, as well as government departments and officials.<ref>(www.uwindsor.ca/business)</ref>
==Partial bibliography== Fleisher is the author of ten books and more than one hundred peer-reviewed academic articles in various journals or academic serials. The following bibliography lists a few of his recent publications: *Bensoussan, Babette, and Craig S. Fleisher (2013). ''Analysis without Paralysis: 2nd Edition'', London: FT Press. *Bensoussan, Babette, and Craig S. Fleisher (2009). ''Financial Times Guides: Analysis for Managers - Effective Planning Tools and Techniques'', London: FT Press. *Fleisher, Craig S., and Babette E. Bensoussan, (2007). ''Business and Competitive Analysis: Effective Application of New and Classic Methods'', London: FT Press. *Harris, Phil, and Craig S. Fleisher (2005). ''Handbook of Public Affairs'', London: SAGE. *Blenkhorn, David, and Craig S. Fleisher (2005). ''Competitive Intelligence and Global Business'', Westport, CT: Praeger Publishers. *Fleisher, Craig S., and Babette E. Bensoussan, (2003). ''Strategic and Competitive Analysis: Methods and Approaches to Analyzing Business Competition'' (also translations published in Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Russian, and an international edition), Upper Saddle River, NJ: [[Prentice Hall]]. *Fleisher, Craig S. (1997). ''Assessing, Managing and Maximizing Public Affairs Performance'', Washington, DC: [[Public Affairs Council]]. *Fleisher, Craig S. (1995). ''Public Affairs Benchmarking'', Washington, DC: Public Affairs Council.
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
*Allen, Geoff. ''Journal of Public Affairs'', 2006, 6(3/4). *Book News Inc. (2007). Portland Oregon. *Blenkhorn, D. and C. S. Fleisher. ''Competitive Intelligence and Global Business''. Westport, CT: Praeger, 2005. *Dishman, P., Fleisher, C. S., and V. Knip. "Chronological and Categorized Bibliography of Key Competitive Intelligence Scholarship: Part 1 (1997–2003)", ''Journal of Competitive Intelligence and Management'', 1(1), 16-78. *Fleisher, Craig S., Wright, Sheila [http://www.dmu.ac.uk/faculties/business_and_law/business/marketing/mk_staff_sheilawright.jsp], and R. Tindale. "Bibliography and Assessment of Key Competitive Intelligence Scholarship: Part 4 (2003-2006)", ''Journal of Competitive Intelligence and Management'', 2007, 4(1), 32-92. *Fleisher, Craig S. and Babette E. Bensoussan. ''Business and Competitive Analysis: Effective Application of New and Classic Methods'', FT Press, 2007. *Fleisher, C. S. (2003). "Competitive Intelligence Education: Competencies, Sources and Trends," ''Information Management Journal'', March/April, 56-62. *Fleisher, Craig S. (2003). "Should the Field be Called 'Competitive Intelligence?' pp. 56–69 in Fleisher, Craig S., and David Blenkhorn [eds.], ''Controversies in Competitive Intelligence: The Enduring Issues''. Westport, CT: Praeger, 2003. *Fleisher, Craig S., Knip, Victor, and P. Dishman. "Bibliography and Assessment of Key Competitive Intelligence Scholarship: Part 2 (1990–1996), ''Journal of Competitive Intelligence and Management'', 2003, 1(2), 11-86. *Fleisher, Craig S., and Babette E. Bensoussan. ''Strategic and Competitive Analysis: Methods and Techniques for Analyzing Business Competition''. Prentice Hall, Upper Saddle River, 2003. *Fleisher, Craig S., and David Blenkhorn. ''Managing Frontiers in Competitive Intelligence''. Westport, CT: Quorum, 2001. *Knip, Victor, P. Dishman, and C. S. Fleisher. "Bibliography and Assessment of Key Competitive Intelligence Scholarship: Part 3 (The Earliest Writings-1989)", ''Journal of Competitive Intelligence and Management'', 2003, 1(3), 10-79.
{{Authority control}}

revision.comment: /* Disadvantages of cross-docking */ removed unhelpful links; cleaned up
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=October 2008}} '''Cross-docking''' is a practice in [[logistics]] of unloading materials from an incoming [[semi-trailer truck]] or [[railroad car]] and loading these materials directly into outbound trucks, trailers, or rail cars, with little or no storage in between. This may be done to change the type of conveyance, to sort material intended for different destinations, or to combine material from different origins into transport vehicles (or containers) with the same or similar destinations.
Cross-dock operations were pioneered in the US trucking industry in the 1930s{{cn|date=April 2014}}, and have been in continuous use in less-than-truckload (LTL) operations ever since. The US military began using cross-docking operations in the 1950s. Wal-Mart began using cross-docking in the retail sector in the late 1980s.
In the LTL trucking industry, cross-docking is done by moving cargo from one transport vehicle directly onto another, with minimal or no [[warehousing]]. In retail practice, cross-docking operations may utilize staging areas where inbound materials are sorted, consolidated, and stored until the outbound shipment is complete and ready to ship.
==Advantages of retail cross-docking== * Streamlines the supply chain, from point of origin to point of sale * Reduces labor costs through less inventory handling * Reduces inventory holding costs by reducing storage times and potentially eliminating the need to retain safety stock * Products reach the distributor, and consequently the customer, faster * Reduces or eliminates warehousing costs * May increase available retail sales space * Less risk of inventory handling
==Disadvantages of cross-docking== * Potential partners may not have the necessary storage capacities * An adequate transport fleet is needed to operate * A computerized logistics system is needed * Additional freight handling can lead to product damage * Labour costs are also incurred in the moving and shipping of stock
==Typical applications== *"[[Spoke-hub distribution paradigm|Hub and spoke]]" arrangements, where materials are brought in to one central location and then sorted for delivery to a variety of destinations *Consolidation arrangements, where a variety of smaller shipments are combined into one larger shipment for economy of transport *Deconsolidation arrangements, where large shipments (e.g., railcar lots) are broken down into smaller lots for ease of delivery
Retail cross-dock example: using cross-docking, Wal-Mart was able to effectively leverage its logistical volume into a core strategic competency. * Wal-Mart operates an extensive satellite network of distribution centers serviced by company-owned trucks * Wal-Mart's satellite network sends point-of-sale (POS) data directly to 4,000 vendors. * Each register is directly connected to a satellite system sending sales information to Wal-Mart’s headquarters and distribution centers.
==Factors influencing the use of retail cross-docks== * Cross-docking depends on continuous communication between suppliers, distribution centers, and all points of sale * Customer and supplier geography, particularly when a single corporate customer has many multiple branches or using points * Freight costs for the commodities being transported * Cost of inventory in transit * Complexity of loads * Handling methods * Logistics software integration between supplier(s), vendor, and shipper * Tracking of inventory in transit
==Cross-dock facility design== Cross-dock facilities are generally designed in an "I" configuration, which is an elongated rectangle. The goal in using this shape is to maximize the number of inbound and outbound doors that can be added to the facility while keeping the floor area inside the facility to a minimum. Bartholdi and Gue (2004) demonstrated that this shape is ideal for facilities with 150 doors or less. For facilities with 150–200 doors, a "T" shape is more cost effective. Finally, for facilities with 200 or more doors, the cost-minimizing shape is an "X".<ref>{{cite journal | first1 = John J. | last1 = Bartholdi | first2 = Kevin R. | last2 = Gue | title = The Best Shape for a Crossdock | journal = [[Transportation Science]] | volume = 38 | issue = 2 | date = May 2004 | pages = 235–244 | doi = 10.1287/trsc.1030.0077 }}</ref>
==References== {{Commons category}} {{Reflist}} ''Making the Move to Crossdocking'', Maida Napolitano and the staff of Gross & Associates, 2000 copyright, www.werc.org
[[Category:Business terms]] [[Category:Freight transport]]

{{notability|date=September 2015}} '''Double linking''' is an organizing principle developed by [[Gerard Endenburg]], a Dutch engineer, as part of the so-called [[sociocracy|sociocratic circular method]]. It operates as an extension of [[Rensis Likert]]'s (single) [[Linking pin model|linking pin]]. In the sociocratic approach, decision-making is structured in circles. Each circle is connected to the next higher circle by way of the functional leader (appointed in the next higher circle) and a representative chosen in the circle. Both the functional leader and the representative participate in policy decisions taken in the lower as well as higher circle.<ref>{{cite web|title=Principles and Practices of Sociocracy|url=http://www.sociocracy.info/about-sociocracy/principles-and-practices-of-sociocracy/|publisher=Sociocracy}}</ref> <ref>Romme, A.G.L. (1996). "Making organizational learning work: consent and double linking between circles." European Management Journal, 14(1), 69-75. doi:10.1016/0263-2373(95)00048-8</ref>
==See also== * [[Sociocracy]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Management by type]]

Dr. Johnny Gaffney |leader_title1 = [[Florida House of Representatives|State Assembly]] |leader_name1 = Reggie Fullwood |leader_title2 = [[Florida Senate|State Senate]] |leader_name2 = Audrey Gibson |leader_title3 = [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. House]] |leader_name3 = Al Lawson (D) |total_type = |unit_pref = |area_footnotes = |area_total_sq_mi = 3.91 |area_land_sq_mi = 2.75 |area_water_sq_mi = |area_water_percent = |elevation_footnotes = |elevation_ft = |elevation_min_ft = |elevation_max_ft = |population_total = 8000 |population_footnotes = {{cite web|title=State of Downtown Jacksonville 2015|url=http://downtownjacksonville.org/Libraries/PDF_Libraries/Final_2015_State_of_Downtown.sflb.ashx|website=downtownjacksonville.org|publisher=Downtown Vision Inc.|accessdate=5 February 2017}} |population_as_of = 2015 |population_density_sq_mi = auto |postal_code_type = [[ZIP Code]] |postal_code = 32202,32207 |area_code = [[Area code 904|904]] |website = [http://www.downtownjacksonville.org downtownjacksonville.com] |timezone = |utc_offset = |timezone_DST = |utc_offset_DST = }} '''Downtown Jacksonville''' is the historic core and [[central business district]] (CBD) of [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]], [[Florida]] [[United States|USA]]. It comprises the earliest area of the city to be developed and is located in its geographic center along the narrowing point of the [[St. Johns River]]. There are various definitions of what constitutes Jacksonville's downtown; the one used by the city government and other entities defines it as including five districts: the Downtown Core (or Northbank), the [[Southbank, Jacksonville|Southbank]], [[LaVilla]], [[Brooklyn (Jacksonville)|Brooklyn]], and the Sports Complex. The area features offices for major corporations such as [[CSX Corporation]], [[Fidelity National Financial]], [[TIAA Bank]], [[Bank of America]], [[Prudential Financial]], [[Wells Fargo]], [[AT&T]], and [[Aetna]]. ==History== [[File:Map of Jacksonville and vicinity, Florida, (showing defenses). Surveyed April 1864. (Signed) Wm. H. Dennis, U. S.... - NARA - 305631.jpg|thumb|left|Jacksonville, April 1864]] The site of modern Downtown Jacksonville originated at a crossing of the [[St. Johns River]] known to the [[Seminole]] as ''Wacca Pilatka'', to the Spanish as the ''Pass de San Nicolas'', and to later British settlers as the Cow Ford. Histories of the city report that there was once an Indian village at the site called Ossachite. White settlement in the area began during Florida's [[British Florida|British period]] (1763–1783), when the [[East Florida]] government built the King's Road to connect [[St. Augustine, Florida|St. Augustine]] with the British colonies to the north. A [[ferry]] and tavern were built, and when [[Spanish Florida|Spanish rule]] resumed in Florida, Fort San Nicolas was built beside the southern landing of the King's Road ferry. American farmer Robert Pritchard became the first white settler on the north bank of the Cow Ford when he received a 450-acre land grant from the Spanish government in 1791, however, he died shortly after and the area was abandoned. The settlement that became Jacksonville largely formed from two land grants issued in 1816: one to Maria Taylor, née Suarez, and one to Juan LeMaestre. Over time a small settlement including some homes, an inn and a store grew at the Cow Ford, and in 1822, shortly after Spain ceded the Floridas to the United States, resident [[Isaiah D. Hart]] proposed establishing a town on the north bank. Hart eventually convinced his neighbors to join him in donating land for the venture, and the first streets were platted in June. The settlement was named "Jacksonville" after [[Andrew Jackson]], who had become popular among many Floridians for his actions in the [[First Seminole War]]. It was incorporated in 1832. The town grew in fits and starts: it saw disruption during the [[Second Seminole War]] (1835–1842), and the business district burned down in 1854 when sparks from the steamboat ''Florida'' started a fire. During the [[American Civil War]], Jacksonville was home to many [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] sympathizers, and was occupied for most of the war by Union troops who took the city four separate times. The war devastated Jacksonville and caused over half the population to flee. After the war, the city rebounded quickly when it became Florida's first major tourist destination; though tourism declined by the late 1880s growth and industry continued apace through the late 19th century. On May 3, 1901, downtown Jacksonville was ravaged by a fire that started at a fiber factory. Known as the [[Great Fire of 1901]], it was one of the worst disasters in Florida history and the largest urban fire in the southeastern United States. In just eight hours, it destroyed the business district and left approximately 10,000 residents homeless. Architect [[Henry John Klutho]] was a primary figure in the reconstruction of the city. ==Geography== Multiple definitions of Downtown Jacksonville are in common use. Often, the name "Downtown" is used exclusively for the historical core. This is bounded roughly by State Street to the north, Hogans Creek to the east, the [[St. Johns River]] to the south, and the [[LaVilla]] neighborhood to the west. This definition is used, for example, by the Jacksonville Historic Preservation Commission and their book, ''Jacksonville's Architectural Heritage''.{{cite book |title= Jacksonville's Architectural Heritage |last= Wood |first= Wayne |authorlink= |coauthors= |year= 1992|publisher= [[University Press of Florida]] |location= |isbn= 0-8130-0953-7|page= |pages= 22–29|url= |accessdate=}} However, the City of Jacksonville and other entities use a wider definition that includes not only the Downtown Core (also known as the Northbank), but surrounding areas on both sides of the river. In this definition, the boundaries are State Street to the north, the St. Johns River to the east, and [[Interstate 95 in Florida|Interstate 95]] to the south and west.{{cite web |url= http://downtownjacksonville.org/downtownvisioninc/whoweare.aspx |title= Who We Are |author= |date= |work= downtownjacksonville.org |publisher= Downtown Vision, Inc. |accessdate=December 18, 2012}} This area covers {{convert|1234|acre|ha sqmi|lk=on}}.{{cite web |url= http://downtownjacksonville.org/Media/Publications.aspx |title= The State of Downtown: 2011 Progress Report |year= 2011 |page= 2|publisher= Downtown Vision, Inc. |accessdate=December 20, 2012}} Downtown Vision, Inc., which oversees Jacksonville's [[downtown improvement district]], covers an even smaller area of about 90 blocks in the Downtown Core and Southbank, bounded by Church Street in the north, Market Street in the east, Prudential Drive in the south, and Broad Street in the west. Under the broader definition, Downtown Jacksonville is divided into several districts or neighborhood. In addition to the historical Downtown Core, the most commonly used districts are: the Southbank, a commercial and residential district directly across the St. Johns River from the Downtown Core; [[LaVilla]], a historically [[African-American neighborhood]] west of the Downtown Core; [[Brooklyn (Jacksonville)|Brooklyn]], to the southwest of the Downtown Core; and the Stadium District, an area containing the city's major sports and entertainment venues to the east of the Downtown Core.{{cite web |url= http://www.coj.net/Departments/Office-of-Economic-Development/Docs/Downtown-Development/1--jacksonville-master-plansmall-copy.aspx |title= Celebrating the River: A Plan for Downtown Jacksonville |format=PDF |year= 2000 |work= www.coj.net |publisher= City of Jacksonville |accessdate=December 20, 2012}} A [[historic district (United States)|historic district]] encompassing a significant portion of downtown Jacksonville was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 2016. Its boundaries are roughly Beaver Street to the north, Catherine and Liberty Streets to the east, the St. Johns River to the south, and North Pearl Street to the west. This area is significant for its pre-1965 architecture, most of which post-dates Jacksonville's great 1901 fire.{{cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/nr/feature/places/pdfs/16000212.pdf|title=NRHP nomination for Downtown Jacksonville Historic District|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2017-10-16}} ===Districts of Downtown Jacksonville=== [[File:Lauraforsyth.JPG|thumb|right|upright=1|Corner of [[Laura Street|Laura]] and Forsyth Streets located in the Northbank Core]] ===Downtown Core=== Also known as the '''Northbank''', is Jacksonville's traditional city center and what most people associate with Downtown and Jacksonville in general. It is the location of many government offices, including [[Jacksonville City Hall|City Hall]], the [[Jacksonville Sheriff's Office]] headquarters, and the [[Bryan Simpson United States Courthouse]], and amenities such as the [[Jacksonville Main Library]], the [[Museum of Contemporary Art Jacksonville]], the [[Jacksonville Landing]], and [[Jacksonville Riverwalk]]. Several of the city's largest skyscrapers are located there, such as the [[Bank of America Tower (Jacksonville)|Bank of America Tower]], the [[Wells Fargo Center (Jacksonville)|Wells Fargo Center]], [[TIAA Bank Center]], and the [[SunTrust Tower]], and are home to some of the city's major employers, such as [[TIAA Bank]] and [[CSX Corporation]]. :The Downtown Core is sometimes further divided into additional, smaller districts. Downtown Vision, Inc. refers to the blocks to north of Church Street and west of Liberty Street as the "Downtown Periphery".{{cite web |url= http://downtownjacksonville.org/Media/Publications.aspx |title= The State of Downtown: 2011 Progress Report |year= 2011 |page= 26|publisher= Downtown Vision, Inc. |accessdate=December 20, 2012}} The City of Jacksonville's Downtown Master Plan further restricts the "Central Civic Core" to south of Church Street and east of Main Street, separating the rest of the area into other districts.{{cite web |url= http://www.coj.net/Departments/Office-of-Economic-Development/Docs/Downtown-Development/1--jacksonville-master-plansmall-copy.aspx |title= Celebrating the River: A Plan for Downtown Jacksonville |format=PDF |year= 2000 |work= www.coj.net |publisher= City of Jacksonville |pages= 26–27 |accessdate=December 20, 2012}} :The Cathedral District is located in the northeast corner, near Hogans Creek.{{cite web|url=http://www.coj.net/departments/office-of-economic-development/docs/downtown-development/cathedral.aspx |title= Downtown Jacksonville Master Plan |accessdate=2012-12-14 |work= City Of Jacksonville}} This mixed-used neighborhood is home to many of Jacksonville's landmark churches, including [[St. John's Cathedral (Jacksonville, Florida)|St. John's Episcopal Cathedral]], the [[Mount Zion AME Church (Jacksonville)|Mount Zion AME Church]], [[Immaculate Conception Catholic Church (Jacksonville)|Immaculate Conception Catholic Church]], First Presbyterian Church, and the First United Methodist Church. Due to the area's close proximity to the former courthouse many of the residential structures have been converted into attorneys' offices.{{cite web|url=http://www.metrojacksonville.com/article/2007-may-exploring-downtowns-cathedral-district |title=Exploring Downtown's Cathedral District|accessdate=2012-12-14 |work= Metro Jacksonville }} :The Riverfront District, also known as the East Bay Street District and other names, exists in the southwest corner of the Downtown Core, centered on East Bay Street. This area was historically industrial before the abandonment of the Jacksonville Shipyards and related industries.{{cite web|url=http://www.metrojacksonville.com/article/2011-jun-remembering-the-east-bay-street-district |title=Remembering The East Bay Street District |publisher=Metro Jacksonville |date= |accessdate=2013-09-02}} The city subsequently zoned much of the area for entertainment, commercial, and residential uses, creating the "Bay Street Entertainment Zone" on Bay Street. In 2011 the entertainment zoning was rebranded the "E-Town Zone" and expanded to include parts of Ocean, Adams and Forsyth Streets, covering much of the historical East Bay Street District.{{cite web |url= http://www.coj.net/Departments/Office-of-Economic-Development/Docs/Downtown-Development/1--jacksonville-master-plansmall-copy.aspx |title= Celebrating the River: A Plan for Downtown Jacksonville |format=PDF |year= 2000 |work= www.coj.net |publisher= City of Jacksonville |page= 33 |accessdate=December 20, 2012}}{{cite web|author=06/08/2011 |url=http://www.jaxdailyrecord.com/showstory.php?Story_id=533771 |title=In the zone: JEDC wants to expand Bay Street entertainment area |publisher=Jaxdailyrecord.com |date=2011-06-08 |accessdate=2013-09-02}} [[File:Riverplace Tower, Jacksonville, FL, US.jpg|thumb|right|190px|[[Riverplace Tower]] located in Southbank]] ===[[Southbank (Jacksonville)|Southbank]]=== A mixed commercial and residential district on the southern shore of the St. Johns River, directly across from the Northbank. It is closely associated with (and sometimes considered part of) Jacksonville's [[San Marco (Jacksonville)|San Marco]] neighborhood. It includes large office towers such as the [[Aetna Building]], Riverplace Tower, and Baptist Medical Center. Residential towers include [[The Peninsula at St. Johns Center|The Peninsula]], [[The Strand at St. Johns Center|The Strand]], and San Marco Place. There are six major hotels on the Southbank, including Crowne Plaza Jacksonville Riverfront and Wyndham Jacksonville Riverwalk as well as amenities such as the [[Museum of Science and History]], [[Friendship Fountain]] and the [[Jacksonville Riverwalk|Southbank Riverwalk]]. Though historically poorly designed for pedestrians, the city hopes to better integrate it with the rest of Downtown as well as San Marco.{{cite web |url= http://www.coj.net/Departments/Office-of-Economic-Development/Docs/Downtown-Development/1--jacksonville-master-plansmall-copy.aspx |title= Celebrating the River: A Plan for Downtown Jacksonville |format=PDF |year= 2000 |work= www.coj.net |publisher= City of Jacksonville |pages= 34–35 |accessdate=December 20, 2012}} ===[[LaVilla]]=== A district immediately west of the Downtown Core. Jacksonville's first suburb, the predominantly African-American neighborhood was an independent municipality until being annexed in 1887. The area of the neighborhood north of Adams Street emerged as a mecca of African-American culture, and was home to many venues showcasing black performers, such as the [[Ritz Theatre (Jacksonville)|Ritz Theatre]]. The southern part of the neighborhood was a major [[railroad]] hub and was also Jacksonville's chief [[red light district]] for a period.Wood 1992, pp. 86–89 :The neighborhood went into serious decline in the 1960s, and has not recovered. [[Urban renewal]] projects commenced in the 1980s, resulting in the loss of many buildings. More recent projects have aimed at bringing commercial development and public amenities to the area.{{cite web|url=http://downtownjacksonville.org/DowntownVisionInc/HistoryOfDowntown/HistoryOfDowntownLaVilla.aspx |title= History of LaVilla |accessdate=2012-09-16 |work= }}{{cite web |url= http://www.coj.net/Departments/Office-of-Economic-Development/Docs/Downtown-Development/1--jacksonville-master-plansmall-copy.aspx |title= Celebrating the River: A Plan for Downtown Jacksonville |format=PDF |year= 2000 |work= www.coj.net |publisher= City of Jacksonville |pages= 22–23|accessdate=December 20, 2012}} ===[[Brooklyn (Jacksonville)|Brooklyn]]=== Located at the far southwestern corner of downtown, it comprises the area south of Lavilla and north and west of [[Interstate 95 in Florida|Interstate 95]]. Originally a residential suburb, it was annexed into Jacksonville in 1887. It is connected to Jacksonville's [[Riverside (Jacksonville)|Riverside]] neighborhood by Riverside Avenue. It is home to [[Fidelity National Financial]], [[TIAA Bank]], and [[FIS (company)|FIS]] corporate headquarters, and other offices. :Commercial and industrial uses became prominent in the 20th century, and many commercial office buildings were constructed along the river. Subsequently, a rift emerged between the office-centered part of the neighborhood on the river and the traditional neighborhood further inland. As a result, in the 21st century the city re-introduced residential zoning and the neighborhood has become the site of [[mixed-use]] developments.{{cite web |url= http://www.coj.net/Departments/Office-of-Economic-Development/Docs/Downtown-Development/1--jacksonville-master-plansmall-copy.aspx |title= Celebrating the River: A Plan for Downtown Jacksonville |format=PDF |year= 2000 |work= www.coj.net |publisher= City of Jacksonville |pages= 20–21 |accessdate=February 21, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://downtownjacksonville.org/DowntownVisionInc/HistoryOfDowntown/HistoryOfDowntownJacksonvilleBrooklyn.aspx |title= History of Brooklyn |accessdate=2012-09-16 |work= }}{{cite web |url= http://www.coj.net/Departments/Office-of-Economic-Development/Docs/Downtown-Development/1--jacksonville-master-plansmall-copy.aspx |title= Celebrating the River: A Plan for Downtown Jacksonville |format=PDF |year= 2000 |work= www.coj.net |publisher= City of Jacksonville |pages= 2–21|accessdate=December 20, 2012}} ===Stadium District=== Also known as the Sports Complex, is located east of the Downtown Core, and contains Jacksonville's major sporting and entertainment venues. Historically part of Jacksonville's [[Eastside (Jacksonville)|Eastside]], it is home to [[TIAA Bank Field]], the [[Baseball Grounds of Jacksonville]], [[Jacksonville Veterans Memorial Arena]], [[Daily's Place Amphitheater]], [[Metropolitan Park]], and the Greater Jacksonville Fair and Expo Center.{{cite web |url= http://www.coj.net/Departments/Office-of-Economic-Development/Docs/Downtown-Development/1--jacksonville-master-plansmall-copy.aspx |title= Celebrating the River: A Plan for Downtown Jacksonville |format=PDF |year= 2000 |work= www.coj.net |publisher= City of Jacksonville |pages= 31–32|accessdate=December 20, 2012}} The [[Gator Bowl Stadium]] was razed in 1994. === Adjacent neighborhoods === * [[Springfield (Jacksonville)|Springfield]] * [[Eastside (Jacksonville)|Eastside]] * [[Arlington (Jacksonville)|Arlington]] * [[St. Nicholas (Jacksonville)|St. Nicholas]] * [[San Marco (Jacksonville)|San Marco]] * [[Riverside and Avondale]] * Mixon Town * [[New Town (Jacksonville)|New Town]] * Durkeeville == Architecture == [[File:Downtown Jacksonville Northbank.JPG|thumb|right|Downtown Northbank]] [[File:JaxFLSouthbank2014.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1|Downtown Southbank]] {{Main|Architecture of Jacksonville|List of tallest buildings in Jacksonville}} The 14 tallest standard structures: {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:95%; margin:0.3em auto;" |- ! {{convert|268|ft|m|disp=table}} | |} == Parks and plazas == [[File:Southbank,_Jacksonville,_FL_32207,_USA_-_panoramio.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1|[[Treaty Oak (Jacksonville, Florida)|Treaty Oak Park]]]] Downtown is home to numerous parks, large and small: * [[Treaty Oak (Jacksonville, Florida)|Treaty Oak Park]] * [[Hemming Plaza]] * [[Metropolitan Park]] * [[Friendship Fountain]] * Brooklyn Park * [[Courthouse Lawn]] * Plaza at [[TIAA Bank Center]] * [[Northbank Riverwalk]] * [[Southbank Riverwalk]] == Economy == [[File:The Jacksonville Landing, Jacksonville FL, Southeast view 20160706 1.jpg|thumb|right|[[Jacksonville Landing]]]] [[File:Jacksonville Terminal Complex, FL, US (16).jpg|thumb|right|[[Prime F. Osborn III Convention Center]]]] [[File:OneECenter.jpg|thumb|right|Omni Jacksonville Hotel adjacent to [[One Enterprise Center]]]] === Tourism === The following attractions are located in the downtown Jacksonville area: *[[Jacksonville Landing]] *[[TIAA Bank Field]] *[[Baseball Grounds of Jacksonville]] *[[Jacksonville Veterans Memorial Arena]] *[[Prime F. Osborn III Convention Center]] *[[Museum of Contemporary Art Jacksonville]] *[[Jacksonville Maritime Museum]] *[[Museum of Science and History]] *[[Catherine Street Fire Station|Jacksonville Fire Museum]] *[[Ritz Theatre (Jacksonville)|Ritz Theatre & Museum]] *[[Florida Theatre]] *[[Times-Union Center for the Performing Arts]] The following hotels are located in the downtown Jacksonville area: * Crowne Plaza Jacksonville Riverfront * Extended Stay America Jacksonville Central * Hampton Inn Jacksonville Downtown * Hilton Garden Inn Jacksonville Downtown * Homewood Suites Jacksonville Downtown Southbank * [[Hyatt Regency Jacksonville Riverfront]] * Omni Jacksonville Hotel * Wyndham Jacksonville Riverwalk ==Transportation== Downtown Jacksonville transportation options include [[Jacksonville Transportation Authority|bus]], [[JTA Skyway|monorail]], [[Jacksonville Water Taxi|water taxi]], as well as major roadways. === Public transportation === Downtown is served by the [[Jacksonville Transportation Authority]]'s [[Free public transport|zero-fare]] [[JTA Skyway|automated people mover]] system (known as the "Skyway") and an extensive bus network.{{cite web|url=http://downtownjacksonville.org/locations/l-155-skyway.aspx |title=Downtown Jacksonville: Skyway |format=website |date= |accessdate=2012-09-16}} The Skyway has the following stations: [[File:JTA Skyway Riverplace Station.JPG|thumb|upright=1|Riverplace Station on the Southbank Line of the Jacksonville Skyway]] ''Current Skyway Stations''{{cite web|url=http://www.smartmaps.com/test/jtfladtmap.htm |title= JTA Downtown Map |accessdate=2012-09-16 |work= }} * '''[[Rosa L. Parks/FCCJ (JTA Skyway)|Rosa L. Parks/FSCJ]]''' located at the northern most extent of downtown, serving [[Florida State College at Jacksonville]] and the neighborhood of Springfield. * '''[[Hemming Plaza (JTA Skyway)|Hemming Plaza]]''' at Hogan Street & Duval Street, serving City Hall, U.S. Federal Courthouse, and Main Library. * '''[[Central (JTA Skyway)|Central]]''' at Hogan Street & Bay Street, serving TIAA Bank Center, Omni Hotel, Jacksonville Landing, Bank of America Tower, and BB&T Tower. * '''[[Jefferson (JTA Skyway)|Jefferson]]''' at Jefferson Street & Bay Street, serving the Federal Reserve Building and Courthouse. * '''[[Convention Center (JTA Skyway)|Convention Center]]''' on Bay Street serving the [[Prime F. Osborn III Convention Center]]. * '''[[San Marco (JTA Skyway)|San Marco]]''' near the Acosta Bridge on San Marco Blvd. It serves the Museum of Science and History, Baptist Medical Center, and the Prudential Building. * '''[[Riverplace (JTA Skyway)|Riverplace]]''' on Flagler Ave services Riverplace Tower. * '''[[Kings Avenue (JTA Skyway)|Kings Avenue]]''' at Kings Ave & Prudential Dr and is the southern terminus of the Skyway Downtown is also home to [[Greyhound Lines|Greyhound]]'s Jacksonville bus terminal. === Bridges === [[File:MSBJaxFL.jpg|thumb|right|Main Street Bridge, a recognizable symbol for all of Jacksonville.]] Jacksonville is nicknamed "The River City". Historically, life in the city existed around the economic activity along the shores of the St. Johns River. Downtown lies on a portion of river that narrows before it empties out into the Atlantic Ocean. The areas strategic location makes it home to a high concentration of bridges. Just in Downtown, there are 5 bridges (listed below) connecting the two halves of Duval County. *[[Fuller Warren Bridge]] *[[Acosta Bridge]] *[[Main Street Bridge (Jacksonville)|Main Street Bridge]] *[[Hart Bridge]] *[[Mathews Bridge]] === Highways === Major roadways serving Downtown from the suburbs include ([[Interstate 10 in Florida|I-10]]) from [[Baldwin, Florida|Baldwin]], ([[Interstate 95 in Florida|I-95]]) North from the [[Jacksonville International Airport|airport]] area, ([[Interstate 95 in Florida|I-95]]) South from [[St. Augustine, Florida|St. Augustine]], Arlington Expressway from the Beaches, and the Hart Expressway from the Southside area. Other important roadways are [[U.S. Route 1 in Florida|U.S. Route 1]], [[U.S. Route 17 in Florida|U.S. Route 17]], and [[U.S. Route 90 in Florida|U.S. Route 90]]. Downtown is also the southern terminus of [[U.S. Route 23 in Florida|U.S. Route 23]]. ==See also== {{Portal bar|Florida|Jacksonville}} * [[Neighborhoods of Jacksonville]] * [[Architecture of Jacksonville]] * [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Duval County, Florida]] ==References== {{reflist|31em}} ==External links== {{Sister project links|Downtown Jacksonville|voy=Downtown Jacksonville}} * {{Official website|http://downtownjacksonville.org/Downtown_Vision_Inc_Home.aspx}} * {{osmrelation|447792529}} {{Authority control}} {{Coord|display=title|30.3194|-81.6600}} {{City of Jacksonville}} {{Neighborhoods of Jacksonville}} [[Category:Neighborhoods in Jacksonville, Florida]] [[Category:Central business districts in the United States|Jacksonville]] [[Category:Downtown Jacksonville]] [[Category:Historic districts in Florida]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Duval County, Florida]]

revision.text:
'''Emile Bernheim''' (1886 – 1985) was a [[Belgium|Belgian]] industrialist. For more than half a century he was the president of the store ''A l'innovation'' in [[Brussels]], which he founded in 1897 in [[Brussels]]. Soon other stores followed in [[Liège (city)|Liege]] (1899), [[Verviers]] (1900), [[Ghent]] (1900) and [[Antwerp]] (1906).
Besides being an entrepreneur he took several initiatives to support the arts and sciences. He founded the ''Bernheim Foundation'', the [[Belgian Vocation Foundation]] and the ''Centre Emile Bernheim'' (CEB) at the ''[[Universite Libre de Bruxelles]]''. He died at the age of 99.
==Sources== * [http://www.solvay.edu/EN/Research/Bernheim/ Centre Emile Bernheim] * [http://www.fondationbernheim.be La Fondation Emile Bernheim] {{fr icon}} * [http://www.trends.be/articles/index.jsp?siteID=4&articleID=44060 Bernheim maakte innovation groot] (Dutch)
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}}
