[[Kentucky State University]] |signature = Yingluck Shinawatra's Hand.jpg |position = 28th Prime Minister of Thailand }} '''Yingluck Shinawatra''' ({{lang-th|ยิ่งลักษณ์ ชินวัตร}}, {{RTGS|''Yinglak Chinnawat''}}, {{IPA-th|jîŋ.lák t͡ɕʰīn.nā.wát|pron}}; born 21 June 1967), nicknamed '''Pou''' ({{lang-th|ปู}}, {{RTGS|''Pu''}}, {{IPA-th|pūː|pron}}, meaning "crab"),{{cite news |script-title=th:'ปู'ปัดบินฮ่องกงพบพี่ชาย ไม่รู้'สมศักดิ์'อยากร่วมรบ. |date=8 July 2011 |language=Thai |newspaper=Thairath |location=Bangkok |trans-title=""Pu" denied flying to Hong Kong to see her brother, not knowing "Somsak"'s joining coaliation" |url=http://www.thairath.co.th/content/pol/184858 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66fnSsEmj?url=http://www.thairath.co.th/content/pol/184858 |archivedate=4 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} is a [[Thailand|Thai]] businesswoman and politician. She is a member of the [[Pheu Thai Party]] who became the 28th [[Prime Minister of Thailand]] following the [[Thai general election, 2011|2011 election]]. Yingluck was Thailand's first [[List of elected or appointed female heads of government|female Prime Minister]] and its youngest in over 60 years. Also, she holds the distinction as the world's first [[Overseas Chinese|female of Chinese descent]] to have had led the government of a [[UN member state]]. She was removed from office on 7 May 2014 by a controversial Constitutional Court decision.{{cite news |title=Yingluck, Pheu Thai win in a landslide |url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/politics/245126/poll-result-to-be-known-around-10pm |newspaper=Bangkok Post |date=3 July 2011 }}CNN, [http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/asiapcf/12/17/ta.abhisit/index.html Talking politics with Thailand's PM], 18 December 2008 She is the third [[Pheu Thai Party|Pheu Thai]] Prime minister removed from office by the Constitution Court. Born in [[Chiang Mai Province]] into a wealthy family of [[Hakka]] [[Thai Chinese|Chinese descent]],{{Cite web |url=http://shanghaiist.com/2014/11/01/yingluckthaksin_go_on_a_family_trip.php |title=Former Thai leaders Yingluck, Thaksin visit ancestral village in Meizhou, Guangdong }}[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/1786711/Yingluck-Shinawatra Yingluck Shinawatra (prime minister of Thailand)]. ''Encyclopædia Britannica''. Yingluck Shinawatra earned a bachelor's degree from [[Chiang Mai University]] and a master's degree from [[Kentucky State University]], both in public administration.{{cite news |title=Yingluck to be 'clone' of ex-PM brother |url=http://www.chinapost.com.tw/asia/thailand/2011/07/04/308536/Yingluck-to.htm |location=Taiwan | newspaper=The China Post|date=4 July 2011}} She then became an executive in the [[Shin Corporation|businesses]] founded by her elder brother, [[Thaksin Shinawatra]], and later became the president of property developer SC Asset and managing director of [[Advanced Info Service]]. Thaksin served as Prime Minister from 2001 until 2006 when he was overthrown by a [[2006 Thailand coup|military coup]]. He fled abroad shortly before he was convicted in absentia of using his position to increase his own wealth. He has since lived in self-imposed exile to avoid his sentence in prison. In May 2011, the Pheu Thai Party, which maintains close ties to Thaksin, nominated Yingluck as their candidate for Prime Minister in the [[Thai general election, 2011|2011 election]].{{cite news|first=Daniel Ten |last=Kate |title=Sister of Fugitive Ex-Premier Thaksin Chosen as Leader of Opposition Party |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-05-16/sister-of-fugitive-ex-premier-thaksin-chosen-as-leader-of-opposition-party.html |location = Bangkok |date=16 May 2011 |agency=Bloomberg L.P.}}{{cite news |first=James |last=Hookway |title=New Thai Candidacy |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704281504576326880909513312 |location=Bangkok |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal |date=17 May 2011 }} She campaigned on a platform of national reconciliation, poverty eradication, and corporate income tax reduction and won a landslide victory. After [[2013–14 Thai political crisis|mass protests against her government in late 2013]], she asked for a dissolution of parliament on 9 December 2013, triggering a snap election, but continued to act as [[Caretaker government|caretaker]] prime minister.{{Cite web|title = Thailand Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra Dissolves Parliament, Calls for Elections|url = http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/12/09/thailand-prime-minister-yingluck-shinawatra-dissolves-parliament-calls-for-elections.html|website = The Daily Beast|date = 9 December 2013|accessdate = 18 August 2015|first = Lennox|last = Samuels}} On 7 May 2014, the [[Constitutional Court of Thailand]] removed Yingluck Shinawatra from the office of caretaker prime minister and defence minister following [[2013–14 Thai political crisis|months of political crisis]]. The court found her guilty of charges of abuse of power over the removal of national security chief Thawil Pliensri in 2011.{{cite web|author=Jonathan Head |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-27292633 |title=BBC News - Thailand court ousts PM Yingluck Shinawatra |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=10 May 2014}} In the wake of the [[2014 Thai coup d'état|May 2014 military coup]], Yingluck was arrested along with former cabinet ministers and political leaders of all parties and held at an army camp for a few days while the coup was consolidated. She was tried in 2016 but did not appear in court in August 2017 for the verdict. An arrest warrant was issued. She reportedly fled the country. In September 2017, she was found guilty in absentia and sentenced to five years in prison. She is rumoured to now be in London, England. == Early life and business career == [[File:Yingluck Shinawatra at US Embassy, Bangkok, July 2011.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Yingluck Shinawatra at [[Embassy of the United States, Bangkok|US Embassy in Bangkok]], July 2011]] Yingluck Shinawatra is the youngest of nine children of Loet Shinawatra and Yindi Ramingwong.{{cite book|title=The Statesman's Yearbook 2015: The Politics, Cultures and Economies of the World|date=27 December 2016|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-1-349-67278-3|page=1202|url=https://books.google.com/?id=YtvMDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA1202&dq=yingluck+shinawatra+born+1967#v=onepage&q&f=false}}Bangkok Post, [http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/local/237309/pheu-thai-picks-yingluck-for-pm Pheu Thai picks Yingluck for PM], 16 June 2011Seth Mydans: [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/13/world/asia/13thai.html?ref=yingluckshinawatra ''Candidate in Thailand Follows Path of Kin'']. ''New York Times'', 12 June 2011 Her father was a businessman and member of parliament for Chiang Mai.The Economist, [http://www.economist.com/node/21521969 Too hot for the generals], 15 June 2011 She is a descendant of a former monarch of Chiang Mai through her maternal grandmother, Princess Chanthip na Chiangmai (Great-great-granddaughter of King Thammalangka of Chiang Mai). Yingluck grew up in Chiang Mai and attended Regina Coeli College, a private girls' school, for the lower secondary level, followed by Yupparaj College, a co-educational school, at the upper secondary level.[http://www.go6tv.com/2011/07/blog-post_3783.html เส้นทางชีวิตผู้หญิงแกร่ง ยิ่งลักษณ์ ชินวัตร], 4 June 2011 She graduated with a BA degree from the Faculty of Political Science and Public Administration, at [[Chiang Mai University]] in 1988 and received a [[Master of Public Administration|MPA]] degree (specialisation in [[Management Information Systems]]) from [[Kentucky State University]] in 1991. Yingluck began her career as a sales and marketing intern in 1993 at Shinawatra Directories Co., Ltd., a [[telephone directory]] business founded by [[AT&T|AT&T International]]. She later became the director of procurement and the director of operations. In 1994, she became the general manager of Rainbow Media, a subsidiary of International Broadcasting Corporation (which later became [[TrueVisions]]). She left as Deputy CEO of IBC in 2002, and became the CEO of [[Advanced Info Service]] (AIS), Thailand's largest mobile phone operator. After the sale of [[Shin Corporation]] (the parent company of AIS) to [[Temasek Holdings]], Yingluck resigned from AIS, but remained Managing Director of SC Asset Co Ltd, the Shinawatra family property development company. She was investigated by Thailand's Securities and Exchange Commission regarding possible insider trading after she sold shares of her AIS stock for a profit prior to the [[Sale of Shin Corporation to Temasek Holdings|sale of the Shin Corporation to Temasek Holdings]]. However, no charges were filed.{{cite news |first=Somluck | last=Srimalee |title=SC Asset to invest Bt2 billion in 2007 |url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2007/02/02/business/business_30025727.php |newspaper=The Nation |location=Thailand|date=2 February 2007 }} Yingluck Shinawatra is also a committee member and secretary of the [[Thaicom]] Foundation. Yingluck received 0.68 percent of Shin Corp shares out of the 46.87 percent that [[Thaksin Shinawatra]] and his then-wife held in 1999. The military junta-appointed [[Assets Examination Committee (Thailand)|Assets Examination Committee]] charged that Yingluck made up false transactions and that "there were no real payments for each Ample Rich Co., Ltd shares sold" and "the transactions were made at a cost basis of par value in order to avoid income taxes, and all the dividends paid out by Shin to those people were transferred to [her sister-in-law] Potjaman's bank accounts". However, the AEC did not pursue a case against her.{{cite news |title= Special Report: Thaksin´s 76 bn THB asset seizure case |url=http://202.47.224.92/en/news.php?id=255302100028 |location=Bangkok |date=10 February 2010 |agency=NNT }} Yingluck, in response, claimed that "her family has been a victim of political persecution".{{cite news |first=Kesinee |last=Taengkhio |title=Thaksin assets case verdict due in January |url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/home/Thaksin-assets-case-verdict-due-in-January-30118876.html |location=Bangkok |newspaper=The Nation (Thailand) |date=21 December 2009}} She has one son, Supasek, with her [[Cohabitation|common law husband]], Anusorn Amornchat. Anusorn was an executive of the [[Charoen Pokphand]] Group and managing director of M Link Asia Corporation PCL.Varinthorn.com, [http://www.varinthorn.com/WordPress/?p=1159 อภิสิทธิ์ กับ ยิ่งลักษณ์ นายกแบบไหนที่ประชาชนต้องการ], 6 June 2011 Her sister, Yaowapa Wongsawat, is the wife of former prime minister, [[Somchai Wongsawat]]. == Political career == === Establishment of the Pheu Thai Party === After the governing [[People's Power Party (Thailand)|People's Power party]] was dissolved and its executive board was banned from political activity for five years by the [[Constitutional Court of Thailand|Constitutional Court]] on 2 December 2008,{{cite news |title=Thai premier banned from politics, ruling party dissolved: court |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hfJ-lAMzPxNPjyXUtOzsYlEvJeow |location=Bangkok |date= 1 December 2008 |agency=AFP }} the former People's Power Party MPs formed the Pheu Thai Party. Yingluck was asked to become the party's leader, but she declined, saying that she had no desire to be prime minister and wanted to concentrate on business.{{cite news |script-title=th:ก๊ก"มิ่งขวัญ"ขวาง"ยิ่งลักษณ์"นั่งหัวหน้า พท. อ้าง"ผู้จัดการอำนาจ"ไม่ปลื้มนามสกุล"ชินวัตร" |date=6 January 2011 |language=Thai |newspaper=Matichon Online |location=Bangkok |trans-title="Mingkwan" faction obstructs "Yingluck" as PTP leader, claims "power manager" does not like surname "Shinawatra"}} [[Yongyuth Wichaidit]] became the leader of the party. US diplomatic cables [[Cablegate|leaked]] in 2011 revealed that during a 9 September 2009 meeting, former Deputy Prime Minister and "close Thaksin ally" Sompong Amornvivat told Ambassador to Thailand Eric John that he did not envision a big role for Yingluck in the Pheu Thai Party, and that "Thaksin himself was not eager to raise her profile within the party, and was more focused on finding ways to keep his own hand active in politics." However, in a subsequent cable dated 25 November 2009, the ambassador noted that in a meeting with Yingluck, she spoke with confidence about the "operations, strategy and goals" of the Pheu Thai party and seemed "far more poised" than in previous meetings. The cable cited Yingluck saying that, "Someone could easily emerge relatively late in the game to take the reins of the party and serve as the next Prime Minister."AP, [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1A1-a36bd1d5cd074db89149230b913a05db.html US envoy in 2009 forecast rise of Thaksin's sister], 14 June 2011 Yingluck's bank account was among 86 accounts that the Abhisit government accused of being used to finance the [[United Front for Democracy Against Dictatorship|Red Shirt]] protesters during their [[2010 Thai political protests|demonstrations in 2010]]. Abhisit accused the Red Shirts of trying to overthrow the monarchy, something they denied. However, the government did not pursue any legal action against her. The Department for Special Investigation found that from 28 April 2009 to May 2010, 150 million baht was deposited into one of her accounts while 166 million baht was withdrawn. On 28 April 2010 alone, 144 million baht was withdrawn.{{cite news |script-title=th:ดีเอสไอโชว์ผลงานตรวจท่อน้ำเลี้ยงเสื้อแดง |date=17 June 2010 |language=Thai |newspaper=Post Today |location=Bangkok |trans-title=DSI shows red shirt funding |agency=Siam Intelligence }} === Pheu Thai Party leadership === Yongyuth had stated his intention of resigning as party leader in late 2010. Speculation about a snap election in early 2011 heightened internal debate over the party leadership. The front runners were Yingluck and Mingkwan Sangsuwan, who had led the opposition in an unsuccessful [[motion of no confidence]] against the [[Democrat Party (Thailand)|Democrat Party]]-led coalition government. As late as 28 January 2011, Yingluck continued to rule out the party leadership, repeating that she wanted to focus on business. However, she was endorsed by veteran politician [[Chalerm Yubamrung]].{{cite news |first=Srisamorn |last=Phoosuphanusorn |title=Yingluck rules out taking Puea Thai helm |url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/politics/218585/yingluck-rules-out-taking-puea-thai-helm |newspaper=Bangkok Post |date=28 January 2011 }} On 16 May 2011, the Pheu Thai party voted to name Yingluck as their top candidate under the [[Party-list proportional representation|party-list]] system (and presumably be the party's nominee for Prime Minister) for parliamentary election scheduled for 3 July. However, she was not made party leader and did not join the party's executive board. The ultimate decision was made by Thaksin himself. "Some said she is my nominee. That's not true. But it can be said that Yingluck is my clone... Another important thing is that Ms Yingluck is my sister and she can make decisions for me. She can say 'yes' or 'no' on my behalf," noted Thaksin in an interview.{{Citation |newspaper=Bangkok Post |url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/politics/237363/yingluck-takes-centre-stage |title=Yingluck takes centre stage |date=17 May 2011}} === 2011 election and rise to premiership === {{main|Thai general election, 2011}} ==== Election campaign ==== Pheu Thai campaigned with a slogan of "Thaksin thinks, Pheu Thai acts".{{Citation |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-14009184 |title=Thailand army 'will accept' Thaksin sister election win |publisher=BBC News |date=4 July 2011}} Yingluck's main campaign theme was [[Conflict resolution|reconciliation]] following the [[2008–2010 Thai political crisis|extended political crisis from 2008 to 2010]], culminating in the [[2010 Thai military crackdown|military crackdown on protesters]] which left nearly 100 protesters dead and thousands injured. She promised to empower the Independent Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Thailand (ITRC), the panel that the Democrat-led government had set up to investigate the killings.{{cite news |title=Yingluck: We'll reconcile |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/SEAsia/Story/STIStory_686725.html |newspaper=The Straits Times |date=3 July 2011 }} The ITRC had complained that its work was hampered by the military and the government.{{cite news |first=Achara |last=Ashayagachat |title=One year on, truth about crackdown remains elusive |url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/politics/232901/one-year-on-truth-about-crackdown-remains-elusive |newspaper=Bangkok Post |date=21 April 2011 }} Yingluck also proposed a general [[amnesty]] for all major politically motivated incidents that had taken place since the 2006 coup, which could include the coup itself, court rulings banning [[Thai Rak Thai Party|Thai Rak Thai]] and [[People's Power Party (Thailand)|People's Power Party]] leaders from seeking office, the [[People's Alliance for Democracy]] (PAD) seizures of Government House and [[Seizure of Don Muang and Suvarnabhumi Airports|Don Muang and Suvarnabhumi Airports]], the military crackdowns of 2009 and 2010, and the conviction of Thaksin Shinawatra for abuse of power.Xin Hua, [http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/database/2011-07/04/c_13964544_2.htm Profile: Yingluck Shinawatra], 4 July 2011 The proposal was fiercely attacked by the government, who claimed that it would specifically give amnesty to Thaksin, and also result in the return to him of the 46 billion [[Thai baht|baht]] of his wealth that the government had seized as a penalty. However, Yingluck denied that the return of seized assets was a priority for the Pheu Thai party, and repeated that she had no intention of giving amnesty to any one person. Abhisit claimed outright that Yingluck was lying and that amnesty to Thaksin actually was the Pheu Thai party's policy.Abhisit Vejjajiva, [http://www.facebook.com/notes/abhisit-vejjajiva/จากใจอภิสิทธิ์ถึงคนไทยทั้งประเทศ-6/218400991534000 จากใจอภิสิทธิ์ถึงคนไทยทั้งประเทศ]{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} The government blamed Pheu Thai for the bloodshed during the military crackdown.{{cite news |title=Abhisit: It's us or chaos |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/SEAsia/Story/STIStory_686726.html |newspaper=The Straits Times |date=3 July 2011 }} Yingluck described a 2020 vision for the [[poverty alleviation|elimination of poverty]].Daily News, [http://www.dailynews.co.th/newstartpage/index.cfm?page=content&contentId=148588&categoryID=680 ยิ่งลักษณ์เปิดวิสัยทัศน์ 2020 คนไทยหายจน], 2 June 2011 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160611191600/http://www.dailynews.co.th/newstartpage/index.cfm?page=content&contentId=148588&categoryID=680 |date=11 June 2016 }} She promised to reduce the [[corporate income tax]] from 30 percent to 23 percent and then 20 percent by 2013 and to raise the minimum wage to 300 baht per day and the minimum wage for university graduates to 15,000 baht per month. Her agricultural policies included improving operating cashflow to farmers and providing loans of up to 70 percent of expected income, based on a guaranteed rice price of 15,000 [[Thai baht|baht]] per ton.{{cite news |first=Jon |last=Fernquest |title=Credit cards for farmers and more |url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/learning/learning-from-news/239306/agricultural-policy-platforms |newspaper=Bangkok Post |date=27 May 2011 }} She also planned to provide free public [[Wi-Fi]] and a [[Tablet computer|tablet PC]] to every schoolchild (a Thai Rak Thai Party plan to provide [[OLPC|one laptop per child]] was cancelled after the 2006 military coup).Yingluck Shinawatra, [http://www.facebook.com/note.php?note_id=186419291413820 วิเคราะห์ โครงการคอมพิวเตอร์มือถือสำหรับนักเรียนทุกคน (One Tablet PC Per Child) ของพรรคเพื่อไทย], Thursday, 30 June 2011 at 5:46 pm{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} ==== Election results and the establishment of the government ==== [[Exit polls]] indicated a landslide victory, with Pheu Thai projected to win as many as 310 seats in the 500-seat [[House of Representatives of Thailand|parliament]].{{cite news | title = Yingluck Shinawatra opposition leads Thai exit polls | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-14007483 | publisher = BBC News | date = 3 July 2011| accessdate=5 July 2011}} However, the official result was 265 seats and 47 percent of the vote for Pheu Thai, with a 75.03 percent election turnout rate.{{cite news |title=Official balloting outcome |url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2011/07/05/national/Official-balloting-outcome-30159554.html |location=Bangkok |newspaper=The Nation (Thailand) |date=5 July 2011 }} There were 3 million invalid ballots; the large number was cited as the cause for the difference between the exit poll results and the official count.NNA News, [http://breakingnews.nationchannel.com/read.php?newsid=518193], 3 กค. 2554 20:09 น. It was only the 2nd time in Thai history that a single party won more than half of the seats in parliament; the first time was in 2005 with Thaksin's own Thai Rak Thai Party. United Nations secretary-general [[Ban Ki-moon]] welcomed the outcome of the elections and called for all parties to "respect the will of the Thai people as expressed through the democratic process." [[Aung San Su Kyi]] congratulated Yingluck, praised the election as "free and fair," and said that she expected "the ties between Myanmar and Thailand to get better."Reuters, [https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/05/us-myanmar-suukyi-idUSTRE7641AG20110705 Myanmar's Suu Kyi keeps low profile on upcountry trip], 5 July 2011{{cite news |first=Lamphai |last=Intathep |title=Suu Kyi welcomes outcome |url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/local/245633/suu-kyi-welcomes-outcome |agency=AFP |newspaper=Bangkok Post |date=6 July 2011 }} Yingluck quickly formed a coalition with the [[Chartthaipattana Party|Chartthaipattana]] (19 seats), [[Chart Pattana Puea Pandin Party|Chart Pattana Puea Pandin]] (7 seats), and [[Phalang Chon Party|Phalang Chon]] (7 seats), and [[Mahachon Party|Mahachon]] (1 seat), and New Democracy (1 seat) parties, giving her a total of 300 seats.Jagran Post, Yingluck to lead Thailand coalition; military accepts poll verdict, 5 July 2011{{Citation |url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/local/245905/new-democrat-6th-in-yingluck-coalition |title=NDP joins coalition |newspaper=Bangkok Post |date=7 July 2011 |accessdate=9 August 2011}} Outgoing [[Ministry of Defence (Thailand)|Defense Minister]] General [[Prawit Wongsuwan]] said that he accepted the election results, and after having talked with military leaders, would not intervene.{{cite news |title=Gen Prawit: Army accepts election |url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/politics/245365/thai-military-accepts-election-defence-minister |agency=AFP |newspaper=Bangkok Post |date=4 July 2011 }} == Prime Minister of Thailand, 2011–2014 == [[File:Yingluck and Obama.jpg|thumb|250px|left|Yingluck greeting US President [[Barack Obama]] at the ASEAN Summit in Nusa Dua, [[Bali]], [[Indonesia]], 18 November 2011]] [[File:Yingluck Shinawatra - World Economic Forum Annual Meeting 2012.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Yingluck at the [[World Economic Forum]], January 2012]] [[File:Meeting with Prime Minister of Thailand Yingluck Shinawatra and Vladimir Putin 03.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Yingluck with Russian President [[Vladimir Putin]] at the APEC summit in [[Vladivostok]], Russia, 8 September 2012]] Following the [[2011 Thai elections|general election]], the first separate session of the House of Representatives was held in the morning of 5 August to select a new Prime Minister.{{cite web |url=http://www.thairath.co.th/content/pol/191224 |title= Assembly convoked to select PM this 5 August |date= 3 August 2011 | publisher = Thairath |accessdate=3 August 2011 | language = Thai}} 296 of the 500 members of parliament voted to approve the premiership of Yingluck Shinawatra, three disapproved, and 197 abstained. Four Democrat lawmakers were absent.{{Citation |url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/local/250471/yingluck-elected-prime-minister | title =Yingluck elected prime minister |newspaper=Bangkok Post |date=5 August 2011 |accessdate=5 August 2011}}{{cite web |url= http://breakingnews.nationchannel.com/read.php?newsid=523108 |title= 296 favoured Yingluck's premiership, 197 abstained. |date= 5 August 2011 |publisher=Nation Channel |accessdate=8 August 2011}} [[Somsak Kiatsuranont]], President of the National Assembly, [[Advice and consent|advised and consented]] King Bhumibol Adulyadej to appoint Yingluck Prime Minister on 8 August.{{cite news |title= Yingluck royally endorsed 28th PM of Thailand | first =Santibhap | last = Ussavasodhi |url= http://www.pattayamail.com/news/yingluck-royally-endorsed-28th-pm-of-thailand-5350 | agency= National News Bureau of Thailand (NNT) |newspaper= Public Relations Department |date= 8 August 2011 | accessdate= 9 August 2011 | id = 255408080021 | quote = Pheu Thai party-listed MP Yingluck Shinawatra has been royally endorsed the 28th prime minister of Thailand.}} The Proclamation on her appointment was made retroactive, taking effect from 5 August.See [[:s:Proclamation on Appointment of Prime Minister (Yingluck Shinawatra) dated 5 August 2011|Proclamation on Appointment of Prime Minister (Yingluck Shinawatra) dated 5 August 2011]]. Yingluck established her Council of Ministers on 9 August. She and her Ministers were sworn in on 10 August.{{Citation |url=http://www.thairath.co.th/content/pol/192805 |title=New cabinet set up. |newspaper=Thairath|date=9 August 2011 |accessdate=9 August 2011}} They were then required to complete addressing their administrative policy to the National Assembly. According to the Constitution, the address had to be made within fifteen days from the effective date of the Proclamation on Yingluck's appointment.{{cite web |url=http://www.thairath.co.th/today/view/192344 |title= Chaloem to be Deputy PM. |date= 8 August 2011 |publisher=Thairath | accessdate =8 August 2011 |language= Thai}} Key members of [[Yingluck cabinet|Yingluck's cabinet]] include former Interior Permanent Secretary [[Yongyuth Wichaidit]] as Interior Minister, Securities and Exchange Commission Secretary-General [[Thirachai Phuvanatnaranubala]] as Finance Minister, and former Defense Permanent Secretary General [[Yuthasak Sasiprapa]] as Defense Minister. Absent from Yingluck's cabinet were [[United Front for Democracy Against Dictatorship|Red Shirts]] who had spearheaded protests against the Democrat-led government. Polls from shortly after her cabinet was announced found that the cabinet rated most highly in terms of economic competency. It also showed that Yingluck was much more popular than her exiled brother Thaksin.{{Citation | newspaper = Bangkok Pundit | url = http://asiancorrespondent.com/62611/polls-show-yingluck-is-the-most-popular-minister-%E2%80%93-part-2/ | title = Polls show Yingluck is most popular Thai Minister – Part 2 | date = 17 August 2011 | publisher = Asian correspondent}} === 2011 floods === {{main|2011 Thailand floods}} The 2011 [[rainy season]] saw the highest levels of rainfall in Thailand in the previous 50 years.{{Citation | publisher = CNN | newspaper = World Business Times | date = 21 October 2011}} Flooding started in northern Thailand on 31 July, a week prior to Yingluck's appointment as Prime Minister.{{Citation | newspaper = Bangkok Post | title = North, Northeast inundated by effects of Nock-ten | date = 1 August 2011}} Flooding quickly spread from the North to the Central [[Chao Phraya River]] Basin, and by the beginning of October, the [[phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya District|province of Ayutthaya]], north of Bangkok, was almost flooded. The floods were the worst in Thailand in over 50 years. Yingluck established centralised flood monitoring and relief operations in mid-August and made tours of flooded provinces beginning 12 August.{{Citation | newspaper = Bangkok Post | title = Yingluck to visit flooded provinces | date = 12 August 2011}} Yingluck also pledged to invest in long-term flood prevention projects, including the construction of drainage canals. Flood reduction measures were hampered by disputes between people on the different sides of flood barriers: those on the flooded side in some instances sabotaged the barriers, sometimes resulting in armed confrontation.{{Citation | newspaper = Bangkok Post | title = Death toll in ravaged provinces climbs to 37 | date = 22 August 2011}}{{Citation | newspaper = The Nation | title = La Nina to raise risk of flooding | date = 23 August 2011}} Opposition leader Abhisit Vejjajiva and military leaders called for Yingluck to declare a [[state of emergency]], claiming that it would give the military greater authority to deal with embankment sabotage.{{Citation | title = Military wants PM to declare state of emergency in capital | newspaper = The Nation | date = 15 October 2011}} A state of emergency had last been declared in 2010 during the Abhisit-government's crackdown on anti-government protesters. Yingluck refused to declare a state of emergency, saying that it would not improve flood management. Instead, she invoked the 2007 Disaster Prevention and Mitigation Act and issued a disaster warning which gave her government greater authority to manage flood control and drainage.{{Citation | newspaper = The Nation | url = http://www.nationmultimedia.com/politics/Disaster-warning-issued-for-Bangkok-30168212.html | title = Disaster warning issued for Bangkok | date = 21 October 2011}} === Cabinet reshuffle === [[File:Martin Zeil und Yingluck Shinawatra 3783.JPG|thumb|Yingluck Shinawatra in [[Munich]] with [[Bavaria]]n minister for economy [[Martin Zeil]]]] On 18 January 2012, Yingluck reshuffled her cabinet, assigning six cabinet members to new posts, naming ten new ministers and deputies and dismissing nine members of the government.{{Citation |title=Drastic overhauling for Thai Cabinet |publisher=Asia One |date=18 January 2012 |url= http://www.asiaone.com/News/AsiaOne%2BNews/Asia/Story/A1Story20120118-322543.html |accessdate=19 January 2012}} The regrouping was assessed as a step to increase loyalty to the head of government and a reaction to discontent with the government's management of the [[2011 Thailand floods|flood disaster]].{{Citation|url = http://english.cri.cn/6966/2012/01/19/2743s677094.htm |title=Yingluck Enhances Unity with Cabinet Reshuffle |publisher=CRI|date=19 January 2012|accessdate=19 January 2012}} Especially noted was the choice of [[Nalinee Taveesin]] (Minister in the PM's Office), who is on a US blacklist for alleged business links to Zimbabwean President [[Robert Mugabe]],{{Citation |url=https://af.reuters.com/article/commoditiesNews/idAFL3E8CJ1DQ20120119 |first=Martin|last=Petty|title=Thai PM gives cabinet post to U.S. blacklisted businesswoman|work=Reuters|date=19 January 2012|accessdate=19 January 2012}}{{Citation |url= https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jhFaoVcAfOolpvbp4Uj8UGsEDCdA?docId=CNG.9081bc8797787335271f45ae49aca168.361 |title= New Thai minister on US blacklist for Mugabe links| work= AFP | date = 19 January 2012|accessdate=19 January 2012}}{{Citation |url= http://news.asiaone.com/News/AsiaOne%2BNews/Asia/Story/A1Story20120119-322747.html | title = New Thai minister on US blacklist |work= Asia One|date= 19 January 2012|accessdate= 19 January 2012}} and [[Nattawut Saikua]] (Deputy Minister of Agriculture), the first leader of the [[United Front for Democracy Against Dictatorship]] (UDD, or "Red Shirts") in the government.{{Citation | url= http://www.bna.bh/portal/en/news/489966 | title =A new cabinet reshuffle in Thailand|work=Bahrain News Agency (BNA) |date=19 January 2012|accessdate=19 January 2012}}{{Citation |first=Thanyarat | last = Doksone|title=Thai 'Red Shirt' Firebrand Appointed to Cabinet|work=ABC News |date=18 January 2012 |url= http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/thai-red-shirt-firebrand-appointed-cabinet-15386024 |accessdate= 19 January 2012}}{{Citation| title= Blacklisted Businesswoman, Red Shirt Leader Join Thai Cabinet|work= Voice of America|date= 18 January 2012| url= http://blogs.voanews.com/breaking-news/2012/01/18/blacklisted-businesswoman-red-shirt-leader-join-thai-cabinet/|accessdate=19 January 2012}} Yingluck's first cabinet had not incorporated any "Red Shirts" activists.{{Citation|first=Pavin|last = Chachavalpongpun | title =Thailand's New Yingluck Cabinet|work=Asia Sentinel|date=10 August 2010|url= http://www.asiasentinel.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3376&Itemid=387 |accessdate=19 January 2012}} On 30 June 2013, the fifth reshuffle occurred in the cabinet of Yingluck, leading to changes in 18 cabinet posts.{{cite news|last= Roberts|first = John | title =Thai cabinet reshuffle amid growing economic uncertainty|url=http://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2013/07/06/thai-j06.html|accessdate=7 July 2013|newspaper = WSWS |date= 6 July 2013}} She herself assumed the post of minister of [[Ministry of Defence (Thailand)|defence]] in the reshuffle. === 2013/14 Opposition protests, supreme court impeachment and coup === {{main|2013–14 Thai political crisis}} On 9 December 2013, Yingluck dissolved the country's parliament and called early elections in the face of anti-government protests.{{cite web|last= Calamur | first =Krishnadev |title= Thai Prime Minister Dissolves Parliament, Calls New Elections| url = https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2013/12/09/249729649/thai-prime-minister-dissolves-parliament-calls-new-elections |publisher=NPR|accessdate=9 December 2013}} On 7 May 2014, the Constitutional Court unanimously dismissed Yingluck from office in consequence of her removing an appointee of an earlier government, Thawil Pliensri, from his post as National Security Council secretary-general in 2011. The court deemed the transfer unconstitutional and therefore, removed Yingluck from office.{{cite news |title=Court rules on PM's fate |url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/politics/408457 |location=Bangkok |newspaper=Bangkok Post |date=7 May 2014 }} A few weeks after Yingluck was impeached, the military coup of 2014 occurred. === 2014 negligence of duty investigation and trial === Based on the 2007 Thai constitution, public officials can be charged and imprisoned for abuse of power and negligence, even without proof of corruption. As chairperson of the rice committee, Yingluck was investigated by Thailand's anti-graft agency about her role in the rice pledging scheme. Two of her former ministers were also investigated, and later sentenced for decades in prison.{{cite web|title=Yingluck to be probed, ex-ministers charged on rice scheme|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/business/news/389909/yingluck-to-be-probed-ex-ministers-charged-on-rice-scheme|publisher=Post Publishing|accessdate=16 January 2014}} Despite being chairperson of the rice committee, Yingluck admitted in the 2013 censure debate against her government that she had never attended meetings of the National Rice Policy Committee.{{cite web|title=PM Admits Rice Panel Absences|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/politics/382021/pm-admits-rice-panel-absences|publisher=Post Publishing|accessdate=28 November 2013}} On 8 May 2014, the National Anti-Corruption Commission (NACC) unanimously agreed to indict Yingluck in the rice-pledging scheme corruption case citing millions of rice farmers who remain unpaid.{{cite news |title=Ousted Yingluck to face impeachment over rice-pledging scheme |url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/politics/Ousted-Yingluck-to-face-impeachment-over-rice-pled-30233176.html |location=Bangkok |newspaper=The Nation |date=8 May 2014 }}{{cite news |title=Yingluck indicted on rice-pledging scheme |url=http://www.china.org.cn/world/2014-05/08/content_32330719.htm|location=China |newspaper=Xinhua|date=8 May 2014 }}{{cite news |title=Business lobbies, academics blast rice subsidies, govt's 'insincere' anti-graft sentiments |url=http://tdri.or.th/en/tdri-insight/business-lobbies-academics-blast-rice-subsidies-govts-insincere-anti-graft-sentiments/|location=Thailand|date=13 February 2014 }} On 28 November, Thailand's National Legislative Assembly (NLA) denied the addition of 72 pieces of evidence to her rice-pledging case. The first hearing of her impeachment case was also scheduled to be on 9 January 2015.{{cite news|last1=Shaohui|first1=Tian|title=Former Thailand's PM Yingluck Impeachment Case to Kick Off in Early 2015|url=http://www.womenofchina.cn/womenofchina/html1/news/international/1411/3142-1.htm|accessdate=30 November 2014|work=Women of China|date=30 November 2014}} On 15 January 2016, the trial against Yingluck began.{{cite news |title=Ousted Thai PM Yingluck in court for corruption trial |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-thailand-politics-rice-idUSKCN0UT08O |location=Bangkok |newspaper=Reuters |date=15 January 2016 }} On 25 August 2017, the scheduled verdict day, Yingluck did not appear before the court, who then issued an arrest warrant for her and confiscated her {{currency|30,000,000|THB}} bail.{{cite web|title=Arrest warrant issued for former Thai PM Yingluck Shinawatra|author1-first=Euan|author1-last=McKirdy|author2-first=Kocha|author2-last=Olarn|author3-first=Elaine|author3-last=Ly|date=25 August 2017|accessdate=25 August 2017|website=CNN|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/08/24/asia/yingluck-shinawatra-trial-verdict/index.html}} 3,000 of her supporters gathered outside the court in Bangkok. Reportedly, Yingluck fled the country ahead of the judgment.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-41046993|title=Yingluck trial: Ex-PM 'flees Thailand' ahead of verdict|website=BBC|date=25 August 2017|accessdate=25 August 2017}} Some senior members of her political party said she left Thailand the week before to Dubai.{{cite web|title=Yingluck Shinawatra: former Thai PM fled to Dubai say senior party members|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/aug/26/yingluck-shinawatra-former-thai-pm-flees-to-dubai-say-senior-party-members|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=26 August 2017}} The pronouncement was then rescheduled to 27 September 2017. On 27 September 2017, in her absence, she was found guilty of dereliction of duty over the rice subsidy scheme and was sentenced to five years in prison.{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/09/27/asia/thailand-yingluck-shinawatra-verdict/index.html|title=Former Thai PM Yingluck sentenced to five years over rice scheme|author1-first=Euan|author1-last=McKirdy|author2-first=Angie|author2-last=Paranasamriddhi|date=27 September 2017|accessdate=27 September 2017|website=CNN}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-41410047|title=Yingluck trial: Thai ex-PM sentenced to five years in jail|website=BBC|date=27 September 2017|accessdate=27 September 2017}} Yingluck passports were cancelled by the Junta controlled government, and she is rumored to be in London and to have a UK passport.https://www.bangkokpost.com/news/politics/1372495/pm-mum-on-yingluck-uk-passport-talk == List of countries officially visited == During Yingluck Shinawatra's tenure as Prime Minister, she travelled to more than 40 countries in an effort to strengthen the relationship between them. Her goals included improvement of trade relations and increased export business investments, and studying water resources management. ===North America=== {|class="wikitable" |- !Num !Country/Territory !Note |- |1 |{{US}} |Visited to talk security negotiations with President Barack Obama. |} ===Asia=== {|class="wikitable" |- !Num !Country/Territory !Note |- |1 |{{IND}} |Visited as a guest of the government for the Republic Day celebrations and attended the ASEAN-India Car Rally at Vigyan Bhawan. |- |2 |{{CAM}} |Helped support the Cambodian to buy products of Thailand, and met [[Hun Sen]]. |- |3 |{{KOR}} |Swearing in ceremony was attended by the President [[Park Geun-hye]], Republic of Korea. |- |4 |{{CHN}} |Helped support the Chinese to buy products of Thailand and high-speed rail discussions to develop joint projects. The Nation] |- |9 |{{VAT}} |Met [[Pope Francis]] in private audience. |- |10 |{{TUR}} |Both sides agreed to free trade agreements (FTA) Thailand–Turkey trade value to increase substantially within the next 5 years. |- |11 |{{MNE}} |Open a new relationship and Special visit as a guest of the government. |} ===Africa=== {| class="wikitable" |- !Num !Country/Territory !Note |- |1 |{{MOZ}} |Technologies into the private sector as Mozambique is a country with a high growth rate. |- |2 |{{TAN}} |Knowledge about natural gas, mining, and wildlife conservation. |- |3 |{{UGA}} |Exchange of academic knowledge, both agriculture and fisheries. |- |4 |{{NGR}} |How to manage nation major source of income oil and gas. |} ===Asia-Pacific=== {| class="wikitable" |- !Num !Country/Territory !Note |- |1 |{{AUS}} |Visit as a guest of the government. |- |2 |{{NZL}} |Visit as a guest of the government. |- |3 |{{PNG}} |Visit as a guest of the government. |} ===ASEAN=== {| class="wikitable" |- !Num !Country/Territory !Note |- |1 |{{BRU}} |Visit as a guest of the government. |- |2 |{{CAM}} |Visit as a guest of the government. |- |3 |{{INA}} |Visit as a guest of the government. |- |4 |{{LAO}} |Visit as a guest of the government. |- |5 |{{MYA}} |Visit as a guest of the government. |- |6 |{{VIE}} |Visit as a guest of the government. |- |7 |{{SIN}} |Visit as a guest of the government. |- |8 |{{PHI}} |Visit as a guest of the government. |- |9 |{{MAS}} |Visit as a guest of the government. |} == Ancestry == {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center | boxstyle_1 = background-color: #fcc; | boxstyle_2 = background-color: #fb9; | boxstyle_3 = background-color: #ffc; | boxstyle_4 = background-color: #bfc; | boxstyle_5 = background-color: #9fe; | 1 = 1. Princess Ueangpheung na Chiangmai }} == Honours == Yingluck has received the following royal decorations in the [[Thai Honours Order of Precedence|Honours System]] of Thailand: === Royal Decorations === * [[File:Order of the White Elephant - Special Class (Thailand) ribbon.png|80px]] Dame Grand Cordon (Special Class) of the Most Exalted [[Order of the White Elephant]]: 6 April 2012 * [[File:Order of the Crown of Thailand - Special Class (Thailand) ribbon.png|80px]] Dame Grand Cordon (Special Class) of the Most Noble [[Order of the Crown of Thailand]]: 20 March 2012 * [[File:The Boy Scout Citation Medal 1st class (Thailand) ribbon.png|80px]] The Boy Scout Citation Medal (First Class) === Volunteer Defense Corps of Thailand Rank === Yingluck Shinawatra has received the rank of "[[Volunteer Defense Corps (Thailand)|Volunteer Defense Corps General]]".http://www.ratchakitcha.soc.go.th/DATA/PDF/2554/B/021/11.PDF == See also == * [[Pheu Thai Party]] * [[Yingluck cabinet]] * [[List of elected or appointed female heads of government]] == References == {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} {{Wikisource|1=Category:Yingluck Shinawatra|2=Yingluck Shinawatra}} * [http://www.ptp.or.th/ Pheu Thai Party website] * [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-13723451 Profile: Yingluck Shinawatra] on ''[[BBC News]]'' * [http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/story/2011/07/04/f-yingluck-shinawatra.html Profile: Yingluck Shinawatra] on ''[[CBC News]]'' * {{Aljazeeratopic|person/yingluck-shinawatra}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Abhisit Vejjajiva]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Prime Minister of Thailand]]|years=2011–2014}} {{s-aft|after={{nowrap|[[Niwatthamrong Boonsongpaisan]]}}
